content:
Posted: December 15, 2016
												I love this game, I actually stopped playing games but I find myself playing this one, building cars from scratch, buying restoring and selling, just to do it all over, for more XP and money, Hell I got so much money I restore the customers cars as well. (If I owned a real shop people would love me haha)But in the end it is a game, even the devs said this is a game not really a part for part gutting of cars, but for the most part you can recognize parts as well as some very minor work. I think brakes, for the most part, but even then there are online manuels as well as actual books for peoples cars.But its fun.... To be the guy that is completely dry ♥♥♥♥ing the customer instead of you the person being boned with out lube when it comes to payment haha.I definitely recommend this game for those of you that are car lovers or are just generally fasinated by what goes in to a car. I applaud them with the DLCs and add ons. Not much for the community add ons but I like the game.This game inspires me to want to become a mechanic, I know it takes A LOT MORE work to become one and there will be no little outlines when I need to rebuilt but i love tinkering and fixing things. Thanks for this game devs. You guys rock!!

Posted: February 23
												Have to give this one a cautious thumbs up. There aren't enough customization options in the base game, and the game is a bit over-monetized. That said, it still plays pretty well and has a fairly good feel to it. It does have a couple of issues that I'll correct right now... 1. the radio is under the window cill behind the Right Lift. 2. The unlockable diagonistic tools can be activated using F1-F3 when in examine mode when looking at the engine. I didn't discover this until 100+ hours into the game. So except for those usability fails, it's a pretty interesting game... Has an issue with part identification in expert mode tho, ie there's no manual to refer to to figure out which part to put on a car if you sold the old ones too soon.

Posted: December 14, 2016
												I've turned wrenches on all sorts of things, from lawnmowers to helicopter gunships.  While this game isn't a "perfect" simulator by any means, it's actually pretty fun and semi-realistic.  There could be a lot more to it, but for what it is, it's actually a great time-waster or way to just kinda sit back and relax.  If you have experience with working on vehicles, you won't find this in the least challenging, but then, it's not really about challenging, is it?  It's fun, as long as you're not expecting a real brain-twister.  As for people who don't have much (or any) experience in working on cars, this is actually a really good way to learn about how things are attached to each other and roughly how they work.  There's a ton of detail being left out, but it's really all about the major parts and being able to customize stuff / repair stuff.The most fun part of the game for me was when I got up to the point that I had enough money to turn my repair shop into a restore shop.  I don't take repair orders anymore.  I go to the auction, find a car to refurb, completely restore it, and sell it for a heafty profit.  It's a great non-frustrating game to tinker around with.

Posted: July 21, 2016
												I wanted to learn more about cars in a fun way. This game does that.I like doing things myself, and learning how things work. I change my own oil and brakes, but looking at the car all the parts were just a mass of inscrutable metal shapes. After playing this game for some hours, I suddenly saw all the parts for what they are. Running Gear. Sway bar. Tie Rod. Tie Rod End. Strut. Coil Spring. There are individual parts, and they have names and purposes.ConsThere are very few interesting decisions in this game.  There's no strategy elements like managing prices or over/under charging, no honesty level, no sales or marketing or competing with other mechanics. The process of repairing cars never changes. There end game is buying cars from the auction, repairing, them then selling or keeping them. Load times are awful for what the game is. The upgrades are boring. The UI when selecting parts can be finicky.I feel like it was a real lost opportunity that the game doesn't offer information about each part. I know I can go hit Wikipedia, but it'd add so much to my experience if I could just right click the timing belt and learn it's function, maybe origin and evolution. What is the difference between a carburetor and fuel injection? Why did older cars have a middle muffler? This would add a lot of resource to the game.Pros If you're looking for car knowledge, this is 1000x more interesting than reading a website or book about cars.It doesn't turn you into a mechanic, but takes the mystery of automobiles and brings them into the realm of the knowable.Your fingernails aren't black for days after.

Posted: February 28
												This review is based on the inclusion of the Total Modifications DLC.Edited Mar/17My original review was a positive recommendation. After many hours of play, I recommend you only buy if on a good sale.It's very simple, like Sid Meier's Pirates or Sims Medieval. You follow instructions and click stuff. There's no skillset involved, no character/avatar visual or animations connected to your activities. That, in itself, is alright. I've put many hours in building/racing custom rods. It's too simple after awhile and all the bolt removal will seem like tedium. The vast majority of jobs are "heavy"; like a collision repair center would deal with. [engine teardowns combined with suspension, exhaust, gearbox and brake systems overhauls] Many engine types are not interchangeable; even between like models.You have to play a mini-game for an oil change which costs you $100 if you lose. [actually, it's just unrealistically difficult to position the Oil Drain correctly, under the engine]The gamebreaker for me is the Repair Bench. It's completely random. You click on a part that needs repaired. Your success rate is based on a random number. At my level, I am supposed to have a success rate of 90%. In actuality, I have only a success rate of somewhere between 60 and 70%. [something is screwy with the math] If a repair fails, the part is completely lost. The quality of the repair is also generated randomly. An item might go from 16% to 100% in one click. It's just as likely to go 16% to 19 to 45 to 78 to 100%, requiring 4 clicks. [1 of which will probably fail]The ability to repair rather than purchase new parts should improve the profitability of "flipping" vehicles, but this system is a liability. I have to save my game prior to making repairs because the math is wack. It takes about 90 secs to get back to my original point in the game, on a reload. I've had 3 out of 4 fail, more than once. Imagine having an order to repair 6 panels and half were destroyed in the repair process. The auction house needs work. This is your only source of vehicles to purchase. Most look like they were dredged from a swamp, somewhere. They are offered with a 1,2,3 or 4 out 5 stars rating. This affects the entire vehicle. You can't buy a car with a bad motor and good panels. If the car is rated a 2, every part on the car will be less than 40% quality, meaning all parts have to be repaired [see above] or replaced. I wouldn't mind this so much, if I coud get a vehicle at a decent price. But there's a "shill" bidder who drives the price of every vehicle beyond what I think it's worth. I've watched bot bidders get "deals". I've seen cars go through with only 1 bid. The instant I get in on the bidding, it's 40 % higher. I always have to pay more for a vehicle than I want, but it's the only way to get a car to build. When you've finished your build, you can sell it for a fixed price determined by some obscure method. You can't sell it at auction.Added 3/17 - 2 other things I should add. Though you can customize your shop. you cannot clean the floor. It is covered with stains and oil puddles. I'd be ashamed to work in a shop as unkempt as this. The second item is the advertising placed in your shop. Although it dresses the shop up with some color, it is advertising, nonetheless, aimed at you, the player. A recent update, did little for gameplay but updated the adverts in the garage. I'm just sayin'.If you get it cheap enough, it's fun building/racing cars. Just don't expect a lot of depth.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												Well where do I start? It can be huge fun and it can a bit frustrating if you want to know how to take an engine apart in a simulation get it. It is a knee deeper in technical terms compared to 2014. Less duct work but diagnostics is harder. Still it is fun taking a whole engine apart replacing one piston, you can do it time and time again. The great features I like are :Engines are done superbly to the detail.Body work a new feature also includes a paint job. Not bad. Auctions - I love those I am already building a full garage of carsThe developers - I´m not sure if it was me but they fixed a very frustrating issue of having to go to the computer when you want to order a spare part by adding a tablet. Cars - many of them resemble the real life ones I found even the one I own. You can get from old american muscle cars through japanese cars, german premium cars, SUV, to classics like Maluch and that one is in real detail I had some fun getting that to work. Dear developers hand on heart do you own it? Music - quite original I like dubstep hehe :) (not just dubstep there of course)Workshop expansions - nice you can unlock a testing rig and a paint shop. Practical details - clock showing the current time for example. And as for most games there is also a huge space for improvement, according to steam forums all the things I miss in the game (tuning, proper race track, multiplayer etc.) are being worked on.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												I got last years game and decided to buy the 2015 version straight away. It's a good game!. Sometime a job will come along in the game and your be taking a lot of the car apart just to find that one faulty part. A basic knowlegde of cars is needed but you will learn fairly quickly about how to take the parts on and off and in what order.  Everything in the game is very decent or better, the sound. the graphics, the gameplay and so far i haven't come across any bugs. There's quite a few extra 'help' in the game like the OBD scanner or a test brake/suspension place in your garage but they cost one experience upgrade which is 1,000 XP in the game, It takes quiet a while to level up, so there's no way your get everything without some hours put in. My biggest problem with the game is the repairs list. You can only see what you need to replace on a list while near the car, once you go to the computer to buy new parts that list is gone. It can be very annoying traveling back and forth to the car to see what you need or you have forgotten. I do know once you unlock repair the items on a bench yourself, you won't need the list as much but i feel the repair list should always be available by pressing O, no matter where you are. Overall i'd give this game a 8/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												CMS 2015 basically takes the 2014 version and improves it. They have different vehicles but more of them and somewhat more detail such as body panels, radiators and fans etc that sort of thing. I have enjoyed playing it though imo there doesn't seem to be much of a challenge financially as it's pretty much a continuous upward climb towards riches. At 9000 xp (7ish hrs for me) you unlock the abillity to buy cars in various conditions and fix them up which is fairly rewarding and has greater financial risk/reward if you don't manage your funds.All in all I wish the game was more detailed (ex. piston heads don't require removing bolts from underneath to remove, many bolted parts are simplified, no fasteners on body parts, only fluid you deal with is oil, so no coolant, trans, gas, wiper fluids etc all omitted, no hoses, no tuning, no interior parts, no glass repair etc. However it is still a fun game, and somewhat educational though simplified.TLDR; If you are interested in car mechanics you'll like this game, it isn't ultra detailed but it has enough to be fun and challenging at times. Do not expect 100% accuracy to real life.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												This game surpasses the original by a large margin. There are a few annoyances, such as:1. Needing to make sure you put replacement parts in the exact spaces they should go. for example, rocker arms. There are 16 of them on a vehicle, if you need to replace 3 of them, you may need to remember exactly where the 3 brand new ones are supposed to go.2. Insane amount of XP required to buy the parking garage, so you can buy cars at auction to flip. 3. Getting some jobs, where you need to paint the the car, even though you still need one or two thousand XP in order to unlock the paint shop.4. A few very minor bugs which happen where it doesn't let you work on anything, because it doesn't think you are looking from the correct position on the car (like looking in the engine bay, to work on the engine).5. Dumbed down some of the dual parts. such as suspension arms, you buy one type of suspension arm, and it works on both the right, and left side of the vehicle, which should normally be impossible.The positive definitely outweigh the negative on this one though. You can take apart far more pieces to the cars than the original game, the parts website has been upgraded with some search filters, and a functioning search box, to find exactly what you're looking for, continuous game play, and you decide what jobs to work on, and when. If you want to work on random job, just go to the phone and pick one of the four options, or after you get your parking garage, you can buy a vehicle at an auction, fix it up, and sell it for a profit.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												Being early in the release of the game and with dlc on the way, this game has impressed me and got me hooked, waiting for more...The detail of the cars is amazing, and while I thought it would be boring, I found myself hooked playing it for the last 4 days.  Troubleshooting and repairing vehicles is recreated in this game, however to a slightly limited scale. If I had to nit pick problems with their product here, it would be only that it is too basic. The idea that you canrebuild a car with a ratchet and socket is unrealistic, and I would like it if they added usable hand and power tools in the future. First and foremost in my mind should be a torque wrench, where you have to look up torque specs and sequence (could be done using the computer?) and having to set the torque value on the wrench and torque in sequence. welders and paint guns could also be neat to use when doing body work or painting. I think automatic transmissions would also be a must add.Im sure some of these features will come in time, but as of right now, im fairly pleased with the game. Id recommend it to any car guy or gear head in an instant.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												I got last years game and decided to buy the 2015 version straight away. It's a good game!. Sometime a job will come along in the game and your be taking a lot of the car apart just to find that one faulty part. A basic knowlegde of cars is needed but you will learn fairly quickly about how to take the parts on and off and in what order.  Everything in the game is very decent or better, the sound. the graphics, the gameplay and so far i haven't come across any bugs. There's quite a few extra 'help' in the game like the OBD scanner or a test brake/suspension place in your garage but they cost one experience upgrade which is 1,000 XP in the game, It takes quiet a while to level up, so there's no way your get everything without some hours put in. My biggest problem with the game is the repairs list. You can only see what you need to replace on a list while near the car, once you go to the computer to buy new parts that list is gone. It can be very annoying traveling back and forth to the car to see what you need or you have forgotten. I do know once you unlock repair the items on a bench yourself, you won't need the list as much but i feel the repair list should always be available by pressing O, no matter where you are. Overall i'd give this game a 8/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												CMS 2015 basically takes the 2014 version and improves it. They have different vehicles but more of them and somewhat more detail such as body panels, radiators and fans etc that sort of thing. I have enjoyed playing it though imo there doesn't seem to be much of a challenge financially as it's pretty much a continuous upward climb towards riches. At 9000 xp (7ish hrs for me) you unlock the abillity to buy cars in various conditions and fix them up which is fairly rewarding and has greater financial risk/reward if you don't manage your funds.All in all I wish the game was more detailed (ex. piston heads don't require removing bolts from underneath to remove, many bolted parts are simplified, no fasteners on body parts, only fluid you deal with is oil, so no coolant, trans, gas, wiper fluids etc all omitted, no hoses, no tuning, no interior parts, no glass repair etc. However it is still a fun game, and somewhat educational though simplified.TLDR; If you are interested in car mechanics you'll like this game, it isn't ultra detailed but it has enough to be fun and challenging at times. Do not expect 100% accuracy to real life.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												This game surpasses the original by a large margin. There are a few annoyances, such as:1. Needing to make sure you put replacement parts in the exact spaces they should go. for example, rocker arms. There are 16 of them on a vehicle, if you need to replace 3 of them, you may need to remember exactly where the 3 brand new ones are supposed to go.2. Insane amount of XP required to buy the parking garage, so you can buy cars at auction to flip. 3. Getting some jobs, where you need to paint the the car, even though you still need one or two thousand XP in order to unlock the paint shop.4. A few very minor bugs which happen where it doesn't let you work on anything, because it doesn't think you are looking from the correct position on the car (like looking in the engine bay, to work on the engine).5. Dumbed down some of the dual parts. such as suspension arms, you buy one type of suspension arm, and it works on both the right, and left side of the vehicle, which should normally be impossible.The positive definitely outweigh the negative on this one though. You can take apart far more pieces to the cars than the original game, the parts website has been upgraded with some search filters, and a functioning search box, to find exactly what you're looking for, continuous game play, and you decide what jobs to work on, and when. If you want to work on random job, just go to the phone and pick one of the four options, or after you get your parking garage, you can buy a vehicle at an auction, fix it up, and sell it for a profit.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												Incredibly fun game providing a good load of knowledge about car mechanics - instant fav!I remember playing Street Rod on C64 a long time ago where I could tinker around the car in a very limited way and I loved it. I'm interested in classic cars (now we have the second classic in my family) and that involves lots of real life mechanical repairs and/or adjustments which made me really curious about how to deal with certain mechanical problems. I'm extremely happy to have this game and getting a better overall view of the whole picture through it. Now it' much easier for me to approach towards any upcoming problmes of my classic :)CMS 2015 is literally an interactive learning material combined with game elements. Great thing, don't miss it!Update: I got my first complete restoration finished: a "Bolt Reptilia" (which is a Corvette literally) - it was a frenetic experience. Taking it apart bit by bit, remove every single part possible and rebuild it to a shiny 100% condition is just like a pilgrimage. The chrome is fantasic under the hood! And also I guess this is how far the game can go really but repeating this over and over again is a joy.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												I know nothing about cars other than my general knowledge of mechanical engineering. Cars were never an interest to me, and if something is wrong with my car, I always take it to someone to fix- never would I do it myself. Not even an oil change.That introduction aside, I LOVE this game. Even without that real-world interest level, this game is polished, sharp, and always has you eyeing goals in the future without holding your hand.  How rewarding it was when I was first repairing some more difficult issues, and without knowing where some parts were located, stripped down the entire engine of a car looking for those parts only to have to reassemble the whole thing- and get it right! It really is a great balance between simulating the work of a mechanic and gamifying it so that it's not quite so world-dreary and labor intensive.I am quickly banking cash and gaining experience with excitement, as soon in game I'll be able to buy a beat-up car at auction and fix it up to resell for huge profit as a side project in my garage.If you don't know cars, but enjoy simulations, progress, and have a bit of a mechanical-puzzle oriented mind, this is a very, very well done game and I highly recommend it. I may not be a mechanic after this, but at least my eyes won't cross in ignorance when someone says "catalytic converter" to me at the garage.Side note: I love the music in this game too. A great mix for working away at the cars in game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												This game is fun and a good tool for locating and replacing parts of a car.  I have some experience in auto repair and other misc. hardware as I'm a maintenance mechanic for the USPS.  Since I'm no expert in repairing cars and I like to learn, I enjoy this game and I've learned quite a bit from the repair jobs I've done so far.At the time of this review I'm only a few hours into it but already I notice some things I would like to see added for extra realism.  For example, hoses (air, radiator and others) battery cables and other major wires, various fluids like washer, brake, transmission etc. and gaskets in the engine would be a nice touch. Something else that would help with the immersion would be to have different size wrenches and sockets with ratchets to use on different size bolts and nuts. I think it's important to have a lot of different parts for the different cars as most cars take different parts in real life; at least for the larger more important parts.  That would be nice to have to look up the make/model in the computer to get the right part. :)  Honestly I don't think it wouldn't be that hard to add that if only they added part numbers to the car part inventory.  Finally I would like to see options of stock, upgraded and high performance parts so you can upgrade the cars you buy.  Overall though the game has potential to take many hours of fun and learning.  Recommended.

												Car Mechanic Simulator 2015. You can get rid of almost every part of your car, test your cars, sell them, even go to the Auction House and buy rusted, busted cars. The best part: Fix them and sell them for a WHOLE CHUNK OF MONEY. Also, there is a Garage, Paint Shop, and Diagnostic Test for your cars when you have enough XP. Store your cars in the Garage. Paint your cars in the Paint Shop. Test your car faster on the Diagnostic Test. I'd recommend this game to you. This game may seem a bit expensive, but it's definitely worth the $19.99 you have to pay. I'd buy it if I were you.

Posted: February 22
												Not accurate and too easy.This game seems to be aimed at people how dont know anything about cars, the type of people who wouldn't play this.this game is lacking many features, there is no wiring, no abs sensors, the engine bays are pretty much empty, no wipers or wiper moters, no interior lights, no exterior light bulbs, no fuses, no airbags or other SRS systems, no MULTI-METER no oscilloscope you can only use 2-post ramps, and you cannot open the gear box to work on the transmission you just have to replace the whole unit, same goes for all other parts they cannot be taken apart, there are many other things missing but it would take me all day to list them.BUT, for somone who wants a basic game its not bad, the graphics are pretty decent but the gameplay is lacking and I hope that a new verson of this game comes out where all the parts are present and where you can strip parts to work on them. Bare in mind I played on the harder mode the game offers so I'm going to imagine that the easy mode holds your hand.But I'm still recomending the game as it's clearly intended for children who would be overwelmed by too many parts.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												So I've recently been playing My Summar Car (GO BUY THAT)... And coming from that to this, everything just felt a bit too simple, a bit too automated and a bit too 'spoon fed'. I'll admit I haven't played this for long, but I've played it for long enough to see how it could get repetitive.The thing that immediately turned me off is how everything is just automated. I feel like the experience would be a lot more immersive if you had to physically move parts, and generally if the jobs you recieved were longer as a result of this, but more rewarding as a trade off.If you're looking for something similar, but will give you something that has more of a sense of value than an XP/Cash number by the time you're done with it, check out My Summer Car.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28
												It's fun to hear the problem of the car ("rattling noise from the engine bay"), diagnose it regarding to the problem and then fix it. Also you got to upgrade your garage with a diagnose-track, a lot of utilities (OBD-Diagnose, multimeter, pressurepump,..) and you can even buy and sell cars later in the game. You learn some things about the parts of the engine, the chassis and so on. It's quite well made and more or less comparable to real life situations.BUT The game just advances waaay too slow, it includes a lot of grinding for experience-points and you see yourself just fixing the same thing over and over again just to get that paintjob-room and in the end it's not that special.It's also not really rewarding as it just takes too much effort to also get the little things. + I'm really tired of changing the f-ing tyres (haha).I paid 4€ for it, I would say I'd recommend it for that price because it kept me busy for one day but after that I couldn't really motivate myself again to continue.But as the normal price is 20€ I can't recommend it at that point.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												The game is nice, enjoyable, fun and I really like the level of details being just right without being way too much nor not touching base. The fewer screws from the last version is surely welcome as is the much better graphics. The bad however vastly outnumber the good about this game.The absolute worst thing is the repetition. I bought the game for the promise of buying broken cars, fixing them and selling them back but guess what, that requires 9000 EXP and 50,000 USD to unlock. EXP is gathered snail-slow, 100 per fixed car and 1 for installing or uninstalling an item. That's 10+ hours for me and I'm still on 6,500 EXP doing the exact same thing on each car over and over again. In a way I guess the developers knew there isn't much variety in the game itself so the flooded it in a way that it needs forever to get you anywhere.I have a decent computer and still the game takes 15-20 seconds to load a car! I'm not talking startup time, each time you take a job, that's the waiting time before the car appears in my garage. Taking the car for a test drive, same wait. It's really frustrating.Taking off the wheels is driving me crazy. I am aware that most car fixes need the wheels removed but the game takes it to a crazy level. If there are 4 steering/suspension problems in a car, rest assured each is on a different wheel. Same thing for timing belts and things that require a lot of unscrewing to reach. 2 pistons on a V engine? Almost certainly on different engine-body parts. Again I think this is intentional to make the game play longer for lack of original content.Overall the game is good, I welcome the mechanical simulation part, quite nice but the game content itself is very short if the repetition is at least limited and the game should be priced according to this criteria, the current price is a highway robbery for the actual content.

												Aside from a few minor crashes (which I'm sure will get sorted out), this game is an absolute blast!ProsFar more in depth then the 2014 versionSmoother performanceThe price!Free DLCExcellent community feedback and involvment from the devs!ConsSome random crashes. (Again, I'm sure it'll get patched)Some annoynances that'll amplify in the late game. Such as trying to memorize a rather large order list on the computer.Very much a niche game.Overall, this game is an easy buy for me. The price, the devs, and the quality speaks volumes to that. HOWEVER, I caution anyone thinking of buying this game to do your homework first! It is a point and click style. Very Niche. And nothing you learn from the game will help you fix your own car. But if you can get past that, then pick it up!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												WOW - talk about exceeding expectations!I was very reluctant to buy this game so close to it's release.... the screenshots and description sounded great, but I was quite honestly - half-expecting to be disappointed.  It was a pleasant surprise to discover that this game was not only bug-free (at least for me, during the 30ish hours of gameplay) - but also a LOT of fun!The game is a very good high-level simulation.  It started off a bit slow, and there really wasn't much of a tutorial (at least not that I experienced) but the game is very intuitive.  I love the fact that you can upgrade your tools (although there is a limited number of options and once I maxed it, I wasn't sure what to do with the extra exp points).  The upgrades are actually useful (i.e. quicker assembly/disassembly of parts, increase chance to repair parts, diagnostic tools that tell you the "condition" of parts in the car)  I also loved the fact that you can go to the auction house and buy cars which you can then fix up and either collect or choose to sell.  There is something very satisfying about buying an older beater covered in rust and dents and restoring it with shiny new parts.  You can also "test drive" your cars - which I also thought was neat.TLDR - Great simulation game that smoothly delivers what it promises in the description (which is a rarity these days). Seems to be bug free and has a very intuitive UI - although I found I had to "discover" most of the things myself since there didn't seem to be much of a tutorial.  This is a real time-sink and I've caught myself a few times now going to the auction house, buying an old beater and meaning to restore just a portion of it... but once you start and then see another rusting component that you just have to replace (and have gotten so quick and good at it)... it really does draw you into spending far more time than planned.... If being a mechanic was this much fun and satisfying (and no grease on my hands) then I could see being a mechanic ;-)Definitely worth the price tag, and I hope that they intend to build upon this game (it seems to me like there are some areas in the game that were left intentionally empty - maybe for future expansions?)I'm happy with this purchase and will be keeping my eyes open for more games from these devs!

Posted: June 21, 2015
												This is a fantastic game! Very addictive. You just want to fix one last problem before you stop playing. But after you fix it, you end up going on to the next issue. I decided to test my knowledge a little and ditch the tutorial. I didn't do too bad, but I messed up when I first started playing. They should be more specific in the description of the issue. The first problem I addressed in game was the front wheel hub. Well, teaching myself how to play, this simple task took a little longer than it should have. After getting the front wheel and suspension all taken apart and getting to the wheel hub, I realized it was for the other ♥♥♥♥ing side (-.-)12/10 would recommend and I will be investing a lot of time into this game. If you like mechanical stuff or are just interested in seeing how cars work, do yourself a favor and get this game.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Huge improvement over 2014 and I like the fact that you can now have three cars in your garage at once instead of one. Its also nice that there is no more loading screens after you completed a mission and going on to the next one. I also like the new Visual Tuning DLC Pack so it is now time for a Performance Parts DLC Pack and also bringing performance tuning back like in 2014 and a DLC where you can do a 1/4 with the cars and a 4X4 pack like in 2014. But other than that great game. Its also nice that you can now buy upgrades for your garage. The only thing that is a downfall for me is that you cant work your way up to having better garages and that you use one garage all the time and also the fact that you need 9000 XP Points before you can sell cars on auction and lastly that it seems like all the wiring has been removed from the engine bay and that the parts are no longer connected to each other like for example the air filter is no longer connected with a pipe from the air filter to the engine etc. 8/10 :)

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												I'm not sure why I got this game as I have little knowledge with cars beyond regular maintenace. At first it was a little intimidating working on my first few orders but it starts you off with simple things like replacing Fuel, Air, and Oil filters, and other simple tasks. Then you begin to work with different vehicles and much more complicated issues where you will need to competely break down the powertrain.Of course it's much more simple and MUCH faster than in real life, but it's been a lot of fun so far. Especially with the unlockable upgrades such as unlocking a Paint room, and getting more tools for diagnosising problems, and being able to repair parts efficently without ordering new ones.I'm still pretty new to the game with a few hours of gameplay, but I think it's a lot of fun. The visuals are great, the sounds of a car lift going up and down are great, as well as the music.

content:
Posted: April 14
												Uh... What happened?The game used to be one of my go-tos for a while. It was relaxing, it was simple to learn, and it was free of bugs... Ever since this last update it has become a nightmare. My floor turns black and lags the game when 2 or 3 cars are in the garage, loading customer cars has froze and crashed the game, making me lose considerable progress, orders from the previous job are now showing up in my current customer's car, and my paychecks for fixing people's cars is cut short because of this. I don't know if this is an everyone problem, or if this just happening to me, but it's absolutely gamebreaking. Not to mention, the Mac version has always had poor optimization in the first place, and lags a considerable amount, while my computer can run much more CPU-heavy games quicker. Maps take years to load, and even on the lowest settings the game still runs at about 29-40 FPS jumping up and down at random. Why? I have 8 GB of ram and can handle much more than CMS as a whole, so I don't see why it is hard to run.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2
												First of all, being a Car DIY person, I do know a fair bit about cars.  It is also the reason why I bought this game in the first place.Car components are held together like puzzles.  Being a car mechanics (in this game), you need to figure out how to take components apart, inspect them and replace if necessary.  At first, it was kind of fun.  Especially it takes away the problems in real world e.g: cables in the way, not enough rooms to work with, bolts rusted up or even strips away.However, after about 20 hours of gameplay, car fixing is so repetitive and the fun kind of disappeared.  In my save, I had 250K cash trying to figure out what to do with it...  Sure you can buy cars from auction, refurbish it, then take it to drag race but that's about it.The other thing I don't like is loading time.  I had this game on SSD (8Gb ram, i5 4570 CPU) but each time I switch from location to location it will take 30 seconds to load.  Its like from Main menu into game 30 seconds (your garage), then from your garage to auction house, another 30 seconds.  I felt like I'm playing this game on CD or something.Game music is kind of cool initially, but after 5 hours or so, you would want to mute in-game music and play your own stuffs.Overall, I do have a bit of fun with this game but game-life is a bit short.  Consider I bought this game while it was on sales (75% off) I think this game is reasonable.  The DLC tries to expand the game-life a bit, but personally, I don't think it succeeded.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												Ahh, another year, another CMSI was looking foward for this (CMS 2k15). In all honesty, the game blew me away.Not only modern day shitboxes are on the game, but classic muscle cars are on here, which is right up my alley. They also grew a pair of balls by adding a V8 and making an L4 with and without DOHC (Dual Over-Head Cam). The only, and I mean ONLY bad thing about this game is the XP system. Final gameplay rating, 9/10.I also gave a brief description on realism of the parts on CMS2k14, so might as well make one here amiorite?Anywho, this game blew CMS'14 out of the water. They moved the oil filter to the bottom, which is what I stated. Not only that, but they added more parts to work on, including ABS, even MORE rubber bushings, sterring rack, and much, much more. I'd rate the realism 10/10.Final rating: 9.5/10. I highly suggest getting this for people into cars, or just want to learn some basics, like oil changes, brakes, etc.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												I liked CMS 2014 but it had some rough edges - fortunately 2015 fixes quite a lot of those!!Obviously it's introduced a few of it's own (it's tiresome ordering large part lists) but otherwise it's a better game in most ways.One word of warning, it's a slow-burn game, it takes a LONG time to unlock stuff (hours and hours of player are required to unlock the car tuning/reselling for example)If they keep enhancing it at this rate tho, 2017/2018 will be awesomesauce - as-is this is far from a light update, there are genuinely good improvements to how you interact with the car, more diagnosis tools, clearer descriptions for the jobs etc. etc.Overall, I think this is well worth a look if the idea of a car fixing puzzle/spanner simulator appeals to you - and I can't wait for the next one! ;0

												I would really recommend Car Mechanic Simulator for everyone who is interested in cars and how they work. If you have the previous version of this game (Car Mechanic Simulator 2014) and you like it, I still recommend buying the new version since there is a significant update over last version: cars now have much more parts, engines and car bodies can be disassembled and repaired. Now in later stages of game you can buy cars, repair them and sell for profit. The game today also got a FREE content update in form of a new car to repair, the developers said there will be more free content updates. I as a car fan find this game really enjoyable and recommend this to everyone who is interested in cars.

As well, when i started this game i bought because of the restoration part... But i got dissapointed, there is endless of fixing cars on contract before you can even get to an auction, you need way to much xp to unlock everything as well. If i could choose i would have wanted to do it more simple like in real life, that you have to pay and expand you way, and not with xp and pay. And except that there is a lot of cars to choose from which is a big +, but it's kinda all the same, because there is not much diffrent motors or car parts. And it explains itself because it is a Car Mechanic game.So what is the Pros and Cons?Pros--Many diffrent car models-Fantastic looking Grapichs-It is what it is supposed to  be-You have a lot of diffrent things that you can do on a car-A lot of rimsCons-You need some damn good patience-It circulates in the same jobs and same parts all the time with small exeption of diffrent parts to switch out-Have to get Xp to unlock, paintshop, dyno, test areas and auction house, as well to pay money for service areas-To little custom car parts, and diffrent ways to tune.-Having to buy all the content because it is DLC and not just normal contentAnd that was it, this is my opinion the game could be much more but it is what it is

content:
Posted: March 28
												While this game is fun, it gets to repeatitive. Unlocking harder jobs means trudging through many simple ones that seem to become more the same. Plus, unlocking all the equipment you would like to use means leveling up 1000xp for each unlock. I've been a mechanic for 16 years, went to school for it. Yet some objects are out of place or even missing. No battery cables to disconnect, not being able to know the status of a part without taking it to a test track even though many parts CAN be checked on a lift such as ball joints and tie rod ends. The worst part is the fact that this game wouldn't work on my old PC even though it met the requirements. All because it was a Win 7 32-bit PC. Now that Im running win 10 64-bit, I realize the game wasn't worth the $10 I paid.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												I had no knowledge about car parts or any mechanic stuff, i bought this because simply i love cars. And oh boy i got hooked. And here's why i love this game so much:Story:You're a car mechanic and you fix'em cars.Presentation:This game didn't really go for photorealism despite being a simulator, and some parts look really funky at times, but most of the time it doesn't really matter because this game runs really smooth and you don't need a beast to run this very smoothly so good optimaztion there. And mostly i didn't really cared about funky looking parts because i had so much fun. Oh, i almost forgot to talk about how much detail and effort has put into this game. You will be surpised to see how detailed the car parts are even thorugh they didn't went for the photorealism.Gameplay:Gameplay in this game is so addicting and fun for both car lovers and problem solvers, so in the first few jobs the game tells you what to fix, but 3-4h in the game gives less infomation about the problem and you need to dig(or shall i say, screw) your way into the car to find the problem and replace it with new parts. Also this game really teaches you about car parts and how to remove them and put'em back in. It is a very fun and addicting IF you're a car lover like me or a problem solver, novice mechanic, or people who like puzzle games. Well if you're not one of those people i suggest stay away from this game because it's not for you.Overall:Overall this game is perfect for Car lovers, problem solvers, novice mechanic, and people who like puzzle games. For those people this game gets 9/10 BUY THIS GAME NOW. But if you're not one of those people do not purchase this game. I myself would put a recommended review because this game deserves more positive reviews.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												This is a pretty damn fine game: finishing jobs and upgrading stuff around the 'shop is satisfying game, the economy is well- balanced, and the cars look gorgeous. However, I upgraded my OS several months back (to OSX El Capitan 10.11.2- I know, I'm trying to game on a Mac, so shoot me), and the game completely broke. Now, I can't get past the loading screen without the game crashing, with no way to alt- tab out of it or otherwise get out of it- the screen just freezes, with any audio from other programmes still running in the background. I recently picked up CMS 2014 on sale as well, and had the same problems. If this problem gets fixed, so I can actually play the game, I'll definitely try to change my review to focus on the fun aspects of the game, but until then I can't recommend it.

Still, it's inexpensive and a good time sink... but don't be surprised if you reach a point where 'what now?' has you moving on to a different game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												This is my Review for the Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 (CMS15) after playing it for about 10 Hours now (which Steam did not record correct, im sorry). Interface I´ve read some of the Negative Comments to this Game and most of them ctiticise the Interace of CMS15 f.e as "poor Choice". I´ve played CMS14 (the Game from last Year) and have to say, compared to the Interace from that the new Interface has some advantages BUT also some Disadvantages.Clearly the New Interface looks more Fancy and more Dynamic then the old one. The old one had always the Feeling of something static is going on with no Dynamic in its moves (f.e when looking closly to a Wheel etc). The new Interface solve this Problem with a lot of good Animations and good Grafics (comapred to CMS14). It also feels a bit smoother in its Animation, which offers a Great feeling when using it.The New Interface is also easier to handel for People who are new to the Car Mechanics Simulator, for Players of the Old one its kind of hard to get used to it, but personally i think thats still an advantage, cause its overall better in the handling.But there are some negative Things i dont want to Skip here: I persoanlly dont like the new Highlighting of Parts at all. Its sometimes very hard to Spot something you have simply not seen, if you want to remove a certain part. Also the Assembeling and Disassembeling is really hard now, cause the Highlighting is pretty poor and bad. Another Thing that is really annoying to me, is the Fact that you cant switch the Conditions View on while working on the Car. That was possible in CMS14 and made it a lot easier to get the Parts selectet you want to select. Now that Function is missing and its quiet Hard sometimes to get the Parts selected or even spot them.But overall its acceptable for Fans in my Opinion, cause it makes the Game only Harder not runins it. Gameplay The Gameplay is much much better then CMS14 for me. The Cars are more Complex, you can Filter the Categorys from the Shop on the Computer, you have different Things to Buy, Customize and so on. And you can Finaly reject Jobs that you dont like, and thats cool.I dont know how many times i had to remove a entire Gearbox from a V6 4x4 in CMS14 and was simply♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥of it (cause its very low payout and very hard work), so finally i can skip Orders like that, yea :D.Players who played the old CMS14 will like the new CMS15 very much in my Opinion, cause its solves a lot of Problem CMS14 had Sound This is a very negative Part for me. I´m a huge Fan of Music and Soundtracks and listen to Music like 5 to 6 Hours a Day. The Soundtrack from CMS14 had something for most of the People. Some Rock & Metal for Guys with a "harder" Taste, some Techno Music for People who like that or some Dubstep for People who enjoy the Electrical Music as well as some good other Tracks. Sure not all Tracks where for everyone, but you could say that not 1 was really "Bad".In CMS15 my Ears are bleeding to be honest, cause this Soundtrack is really awefull. Not only that there are some good Rocky Songs are missing, not the whole Soundtrack is more like a Techno / Dubstep / and things like that Album. F.e there is this Song from a Girl with some Douett Part in it (the only one) and i´ve never heard a Professional Singer in a long time, who misses so much Notes like she did in only 1 Song. And this Pattern of awefull Music is applied to all Tracks in CMS15.If there is CMS16 planned (dont know it atm) please take more Time for the Soundtrack and dont choose this Crap again. Its nice that you want to support "little" Musicans (as far as i see they are all not that Popular), but please choose those who have talent :). Conclusion I´ve said a lot of positive Things, a lot of negative things and a bunch of awefully things about CMS15. Now its the final moment: Would i reccomend it or not. I have to say, personally, i would reccomend it for Poeple who played CMS14 and people who like Simulator Games. Its a good, nice puzzle Game which can provide Hours of Fun and you can acutally learn something about Business Management and Cars as well (not much, but at least you now know where your Cars Gearbox is right?).

content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												I do like this game, and I am a retired auto repair shop owner.  I bought it in alpha and enjoyed it and played it a lot early on.  But after a while the challenge diminishes rapidly.  It only takes a few times to learn a car, and new cars are not much of a challenge.  The DLC of new vehicles are expensive and there should be many more vehicles in the base game.  The vehicles are typically based on a basic format so if you have 4WD DLC your just getting one basic vehicle with some minor changes between them.  They represent different companies but are all designed the same.  The only really different vehicle is the Maluch, and its, just weird.  All in all I played over 120 hours.  You have to have the visual tuning DLC to make the game playable, but they charge seperately for it, so you know what your in for with this game.

												I don't think I've played one of these games before, so I jumped into this one with intrepidation.


YouTube™ Video: ➜ A Quick Look @ 'Car Mechanic Sim 2015' 

			Views: 41		

			You can get the game here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/320300 Massive Thanks to the Dev's for the Review Copy! A non-biased quick look @ 'Car Mechanic Sim 2015' - I don't think i've played one...		

The game boasts new cars, new tools, new options, and more parts. Create and expand your auto repairs service empire. Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 will take you behind the scenes of daily routine in car workshop. Take on the role of the car mechanic and repair cars for your clients. Spend the earned money on expanding your workshop and improving your skills. Buy worn out cars, renovate them and sell with profit or become a famous car collector. If you manage your business well, you will surely succeed in the market.   - Recommended!

content:
Posted: October 19, 2016
												Great idea. The trouble is you don't play a good idea. Your clicking parts on and off a car. All the cars use the same set of parts. There are some tuning options but they are very limited. Don't think you can chop and change engines etc. Limited choice on wheels with no real choice on width or diameter. So you click parts on and off  a car. Then you get to set it up on the dyno. This is 3 buttons you fiddle with till the mixture is right. Doesn't say what you are actually doing and its so random you might as well throw a dice. Then theres the drag strip. Throttle is just a button so if you have a car with decent power your either spinning into the wall or short shifting gears so you never get a meaningful time anyway. Like I said a great idea that very soon becomes very boring.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												If you're a gearhead, but just don't have the time to work on cars as it is, this game is for you.  Yeah, there's no "end game" or "end goal" but there are lots of goals along the way: get equipment to diagnose problems easier, get a place to store cars, buy cars and restore them, customize cars, etc.I played the last game, and I'm very surprised at just how much better this game is.  Initially, I was worried this game might go the route of the city building game, where basically you were paying full price for what was a patch.  Not with this series!  I can't explain just how much of a massive improvement this game is over the previous one, and I had a great time with the last game.The engine is very smooth, and they keep tweaking it to make it run better.  Attention to detail is very high, I'm surprised at how nice the shop looks.  It would have been cool if we started out in some ratty shop and eventually paid our way via hard work and business to a cool high-tech shop, but beggars can't be choosers, and I understand that would add extra development time.The game gets very detailed in the repairs, and I'm hoping the next version of this game gets even more detailed.  The fact that you can dissassemble engines all the way down to the crankshaft is impressive.  There are variations to the engines in that you work on 4 cylinder and 8 cylinder layouts as well at 8cyl with DOHC.At first it may feel like you gain experience slowly, but I feel the pacing is pretty much perfect.  I've put in a lot of hours and I'm only about to start bidding on cars and restoring them.  I'm a very casual gamer and feel the pacing fits my schedule perfectly.The devs actually monitor the forum and listen to suggestions.  That's great!This game is very therepeutic for me, it's so relaxing to just sit back and work on a virtual car.  Anyone who has wrenched on a car knows it's not as easy as this game, so it's nice for everything to work out so smoothly.As far as where this series future goes, I'm just hoping it gets more detailed and realistic.  I'm so glad they have a well optimized game engine as it is, as well as their attention to detail.This game is worth far more than $20, and I would have gladly paid $60 for it.The devs have set a HUGE benchmark with this version,  they have their work cut out for them in the sequel!  Great job.

number of helpful: 24 of 53 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												You basically take apart cars and replace broken parts (which are shown as covered in rust). As you gain experiemce you will unlock ability to repair parts rather than replace them with new ones. Also you gain access to some diagnostic tools which willl tell you what is broken, but you will rarely use them because they'll just color code what you already see as rusty as thus broken. First 10 hours of the game you are likely to have lots of fun, but soon after you will inadvertly realize you have just been taking apart 3 variants of engines and 3 variations of undercarriages stuffed in different chasis all that time. There is little progression to speak of. In fact the only difference awaiting you at the end is option to buy  broken cars and sell them after you have fixed them the same way as completing the repair job. There's no customization, no tuning and virtually no driving cars in this game. If you're looking for that you will be dissapointed. If you're looking for simplistic puzzler to kill 10-15 hours in you will enjoy this title. If you're looking for something akin to classic games like street rod, you will find this title dull and repetitive.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												I understand this is a "Car Mechanic Simulator" game, and i don't know nearly anything about cars.Also i like this game sort of but i wouldn't recommend it to anyone, and if you do want to play it play the Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 Demo its not that much differentOnce i fully pull apart and put new things on everything on 3-4 different cars in this i felt like that was it the only thing more to do is make money and store your own cars in the garage then just have them sit there because there is nothing elsei made a list of the things i dislike they are in no order-the only thing you can really change on a car is its colour, other then that you repair or replace parts exactly the way it is including the wheels/rims-Rims and tyres are one piece (there is a picture with them separate)-Car seems to lack wires?-When bolts come out of some parts theres no holes in the piece it was in-The inside of the boot/trunk has no detail at all-No spare tyre-The shadow under the car while on the lifter makes no sense-No number plates-Cant change interior at all including the seats which also has a picture out of the car-Cant change windscreen wiper blades-Apart from the colour What ever is on the car you cant change you cant- Rust is how bad a part is there is nothing more to that-Some menus feel like there meant to be on a touch screen (the swiping i'm meaning)- No real car brands?On the test track (Considering this is a simulator game the driving isnt the worst)-There is no person in 3rd person view-Cant remember what car it was but it was only one that i know of theres like a jutter when you drive in 3rd person view-The car from the Youngtimer update has no engine when its hood is off, not sure if other cars are the sameFor the people who say loading times when you get a car or go the the test track is 3-5 seconds really that big of a deal..I would of liked to see trucks in this and just have Mechanic Simulator and have dlc for different types of Mechanics, i cant wait for the aeroplane, boats or motobikes Mechanic Simulatorsi do look forward to seeing what else they make as well

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												Like everyone, I'm impressed with the level of detail of when dismantling the car, but the game itself..boring to anyone except someone who does this for a living.  It is a GAME so it's missing things that make it a true simulator. No angry customers or budget for keeping the place running. Customers coming back to say you didn't put a screw or a bolt back...accidents there in the garage..challenges, maybe you get to go to Nascar and have to SPEED repair cars.  There needs to be a clock period. Where you quote a customer a time to pick up so you have to work a little faster. And for the love of god please allow us to add our own music..itunes play list..something.Hearing the sound of the wratchet (may have spelled that wrong) definitely did take me back to being a little girl in the garage with my Papa but as a hard core simulator fan this falls short.It plays more like a mechanic class than an actual game.  I'll give it a good review just because you did an amazing job on the parts.  But I won't be buying any more of your games ladies and gents. You need to take a look at other simulators and add a LOT MORE to make it a true Sim.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												The tutorial is useless. Controls are useless. Gameplay is intuitive enough, though, once you learn to figure things out yourself.  ...if you have that kind of patience.  The main feeling I had during my brief gameplay session was fear of not knowing what I didn't know.Okay, I've accepted a job. Should I walk to the car? Should I move it to a lifter? Okay, I figured that out by myself. Great. Now I've spilled oil everywhere. Didn't realize that I owned an oil drain. Found that later, again not led by the tutorial. Now, am I placing the oil drain correctly? I hope so, because I can't reposition it until my next oil change!

number of helpful: 1 of 9 people (11%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												These games are difficult to recommend.  If you know cars well you will be insulted by how much they leave out, and if you don't know cars but want to learn more you'll be grosly misled.   I enjoyed 2014 more than 2015.  Because 2015 didn't fix any of my complaints from the first game, it would be very awkward to recommend it.  However, it is not a bad game.ProsImproved Graphics.More detail on car parts and repairs.You can now buy your cars from auctions.ConsNo campaign mode.Work orders are less creative because there is no campaign.  2014 would tell you "the car makes clank sounds and accelerates slowly" and then you had to figure out what was broken.  2015 just gives you large lists of broken parts to fix.  Not nearly as interesting.2014 would also have you plug the code reader into the obd port.  2015 has you use the code reader on the actual parts, very odd.You still don't have to add transmission fluid after putting the transmission back in place.  Same goes for anti-freeze in the radiator.  Its still fairly difficult to line-up the oil-catch under the oil plug.Some of the jobs are still absurd expensive, people spending $15,000 on crappy econoboxes to fix them.  Some of the parts are still crazy priced.The interface and controls are still awkward and counter-intuitive.Some tasks, such as removing the wheels, still take far too long.Ok, so the list of cons is big.  Do I recommend the game?  I would recommend 2014 before this game.  It seems like 2015 didn't solve any of major issues with the series and they took some of the core expierence away by getting rid of campaign mode.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												Always start with a JokeA penguin is driving along the motorway eating a tub of Ben and Jerrys Phish food ice-cream and making a hellova mess when suddenly the car lurches to a stop with steam coming out of the bonnet. The penguin covered in ice-cream phones for a breakdown truck which arrives promptly and the mechanic is not phased to see he’s been called out by a talking penguin and gets to work under the bonnet.After a couple minutes the mechanic closes the hood and looks at the rather stained penguin and says “you look like you have blown a seal” and the penguin say “ah no, its Ice-cream”Now that the ice is broken, lets get down to business.Good concept, spoiled by a constant stream of below average DLCs that add little other than new new car shapes.Like all of these simulators, the business side of the game is pointless and only there to slow your collecting down. Despite 70hours of play, I'd only reccommend this on Sale and to sombody with OCD.More than a year on and the developers promised steam achievements are nowhere to be seen

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												Very much a niche sim that requires you to have a lot of knowledge about the subject matter already. There is no real tutorial, help file or wiki to help you find what parts are to be found where. Combined with the ho-hum camera, this means you'll spend most of your time clicking around the car, hoping to hit the hot spot with the correct name. If you're out of luck, it'll be hidden inside other components. Strangely, finding the right parts to replace seems to be the core game component. The other mechanics are bolting/unbolting said parts and ordering replacements online. Oh, and you get to push the button on the lift.The music is very much an acquired taste, so bring your own MP3s. Grab a Haynes manual and a lot of patience while you're at it.

Posted: December 2, 2015
												So. Car Mechanic Simulator 2015. The year is almost over, and I have a good 100 hours on this game, so it's about time for a review.What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said? It's definitely a very good game, it's informative in its own way, educational, and just plain fun, especially when you save up enough money and experience to expand your garage, get the paint shop, get the underground parking, and go to the auction house to buy wrecks you can fix up and sell for a profit.Of course, things are simplified a lot under the hood of each car you get to work on. I'm no mechanic, but I know enough of cars to have done maintenance on my own cars, and I have studied a lot of stuff for stories I write in which a character is an actual mechanic. There is in fact a funny thing about that; the game showed me painfully well how I got most of my knowledge about cars. It started in Dutch, as that is the language set on my laptop, and one of the first customer cars I got in showed a list that said there was a part that needed replacing. And I was all like; what the hell is that? So I saved and quit to menu, set the game language to English, started back up again, looked at the list, and went; Ohhh! Duh, a rubber bushing! Why didn't you just SAY so? I KNOW those! (And I know the name of that part mainly from watching YouTube videos of HotRod Magazine/HotRod Garage, and reading those kind of magazines - in English. For about 70% of the parts, I have NO clue what they are by the Dutch names alone)How simplified is it under the hood? Well, all cars have similar parts, for one. A front suspension has a crossmember, shocks, springs, a swaybar and end links, steering rack with inner and outer tie rods, upper and/or lower control arms, wheel knuckle housing, wheel hub, brake disk, pads, and a brake caliper. All but one or two cars come with a brake servo, and the newer models with an ABS pump and control unit. Brake lines? Nope. Brake fluid? Nope. A need to bleed the system after you rebuilt it? Nope.The engines? Let's stick with my favorite type of cars; the old ones. There's several classics that are all too recognizable; a 1957 Chevy Bel Air, a 1969 Ford Mustang, a 1968 Chevrolet Chevelle, a 1969 Dodge Charger. Of course they are not called that; the game has given each car its own brand and type. Big plus; they have actually taken the time to design logos and name badges that are on the cars, and they look good, too!But, the engines. Those four cars I mentioned all come with a carburated overhead-cam V8 engine. All parts are interchangeable, except for the two-carb intake manifold that comes on the Mustang. Have you bought a Chevelle and want to spruce it up a bit with a dual carburetor setup? Sorry, no can do, that dual-carb intake manifold is not an optional part for that car. Even when you take the V8 out of a Mustang and put it in the Chevelle, you can only put on the single-carb intake manifold. The only optional parts you can change on a car are the rims, and body parts if you have the Visual Tuning DLC pack.For the rest, though, it's good. Quite simplified, but with plenty of detail parts even so. Take apart one of those old V8's, and you find yourself with a box full of individual rocker arms and pushrods which you can take out one by one - and there's sixteen of them in one engine.There's one big drawback, though. You can't take the whole engine plus transmission out of the car in one big lump and put it on an engine stand to disassemble it, like almost any car restorer does; you have to disassemble, and reassemble it, in the car. And some parts you can only reach from underneath. Once you have gotten down to the engine block, it's; take out pistons, lift car, get under, remove oil pan (if you already hadn't), remove crankshaft caps, remove crankshaft, get out, lower car, remove engine block. Fix up or buy new one. Put in engine block, lift car, get under, put in crankshaft, put in crankshaft caps, get out, lower car, put in pistons, lift car, get under, put on oil pan and filter, get out, lower car, rebuild rest of the engine. That would be SO much easier if you could just take the whole thing out, put it on an engine stand, and disassemble/reassemble there.And the simplification shows. The plug wires are the only wires you'll find in the whole car. The detailing goes as far as to put individual clips on the air filter box/distributor cap you have to take off, but a wiring loom for all the electrics? Not there. Gaskets? Not there. There's a fuel filter, but fuel lines? Nope. Brake lines? Nope. And even on the most hashed-out rusty wreck of a 1957 Bel Air you buy at the auction house, ALL the bolts are always brand new. The rims and parts of the suspension/engine may be so rusted they are beyond repair, but they still come off with three turns of your wrench on the brand new bolts holding everything in place.The same goes for the fixing of the parts. You have a work table where you can fix a good number of the parts you take off a car. Butthe fixing process is; click. You managed to repair the part! Condition is now X%! Or; click. You failed to repair the part. Condition has decreased. (and it always decreases to a point so low you can't re-attempt to fix it again. So if you hash up a part, it's utterly broken and you need to buy a new one)Still, overall, it's a great game. After 100 hours I'm still not bored of it, even if I'm doing pretty much the same things over and over again. It just has that certain something about it that keeps drawing you in to play it more. There's just a few little things that could make it even better.- placing of the oil drain pan. That is SUCH a hit-and-miss, because you can't look upwards properly once you're moving that thing around. I end up just removing the oil pan and taking the $100 fine for oil cleanup, rather than to fiddle around with that drain and having it sit just a smidge too far to the left, right, front or back anyway.- disassembling/reassembling the engine outside of the car on an angine stand. If that could be implemented, it would be SUCH an improvement.- customizing of the cars. Currently, it's just visual with body parts and head/tail lights and bumpers, and rims, and only when you have the Visual Tuning DLC pack. If you were allowed to put different engines in different cars, or even do things like put that dual-carb intake on a single-carb V8 engine, that would make things a lot more fun. Also, speed parts would be nice. Take the tame little Pinto, yank out that four-banger engine, plop in a V8 with a high-lift cam, dual or triple carburetors and a turbo or a blower, and you suddenly have a much more interesting car.- graphics. Not the overall game graphics; those are pretty good as is. But some extra graphics for the cars? That would be a lot more fun. Take the Dodge Charger, give it a new paint job, and let us put on a bumblebee stripe around the rear end, for instance. Or racing stripes over the hood and trunk of the Chevelle. Or a spiffy flame-job. Hell yeah.- the test drive. Currently, there are in fact different engine sounds for the different cars, and some different driving characteristics. But the handling is atrocious, and the whole thing feels a bit... tacked on. Almost like it was an afterthought. There is massive potential for improvement there.- bodywork on the cars. At the moment, it's front bumper, headlights, hood, front fenders, doors, trunk lid, taillights, rear bumper. Not even windshields/rear windows/side windows (and everyone who ever restored an old car knows that the quarter panels/rear fenders and floor pans are 90% of the time the areas that need the most work). I can see a lot of potential for improvement there as well, the outer bodywork, and the interior as well. Allow us to put in leather bucket seats, for instance, or give the interior a different color than black.Do I recommend this game though? Hell yes!

Posted: June 27, 2015
												There's good and bad, but overall, it's a worthwhile and entertaining game. The bad: Some things I found irritating was the whole "Repair Bench" system. For the most part you can repair most parts on it, and depending how  many points you have spent in the skill, you have up to a 90% chance of repairing a part. However there seems to be no rhyme or reason to which parts you can or cannot repair. For example, you can somehow repair brake shoes, but not brake discs. Another problem is with the repairs itself... As mentioned, you have up to a 90% chance of a successful repair if you purchase all the points for the repair bench. That may seem like a lot, however given that it may take up to 5 repairs on say an engine block, you really only have a 5 out of 9 chance of completely repairing it successfully. This means you may repair an expensive item up to 89% or so, but then fail your last roll and completely destroy it. How does that happen in real life? I have an almost brand new engine and somehow I totally ruin it beyond repair? I could understand letting it only repair up to a certain point, but the way the system works, even with full points in repair, you end up ruining more than half the parts you pull on any given repair job. Also... how the hell difficult is it to put an oil pan under the engine to avoid a $100 spill.The good: It's fun... But gets old fast. Not a lot of variety. Most cars are different only on the outside. If you've worked on one, you've worked on them all.

Posted: June 24, 2015
												Vastly improved over CMS 2014. Graphics are much nicer and the engines/vehicles look much closer to their real life counterparts, though there are still a few mistakes. Wider variety of vehicles and a larger garage enables multiple jobs simultaenously.The ability to purchase cars at aution and restore them either for profit or your personal collection is very welcome. The only complaints I have about the auction house are that each car gets sent to your parking lot automatically and there is a set number of cars per auction. I do understand that the limited number of cars is more realistic but it is rather bothersome when I am looking for a specific car to work on. The issue with sending cars to the parking lot is understandable and would be more bearable if the loading times were lower.I also really liked the addition of diagnostic tools and a leveling system not based on cash. The only complaint in that department is that the repair skill maxes out at 90%. That is literally my one complaint about the new system. Everything else was a welcome change.The developer also seems to be pushing updates regularly (as of July, 2015) which is much appreciated. Several patches were already released since I purchased this game. More vehicles and tuning parts have also been added as optional DLC.
