Posted: December 2, 2015
												So. Car Mechanic Simulator 2015. The year is almost over, and I have a good 100 hours on this game, so it's about time for a review.What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said? It's definitely a very good game, it's informative in its own way, educational, and just plain fun, especially when you save up enough money and experience to expand your garage, get the paint shop, get the underground parking, and go to the auction house to buy wrecks you can fix up and sell for a profit.Of course, things are simplified a lot under the hood of each car you get to work on. I'm no mechanic, but I know enough of cars to have done maintenance on my own cars, and I have studied a lot of stuff for stories I write in which a character is an actual mechanic. There is in fact a funny thing about that; the game showed me painfully well how I got most of my knowledge about cars. It started in Dutch, as that is the language set on my laptop, and one of the first customer cars I got in showed a list that said there was a part that needed replacing. And I was all like; what the hell is that? So I saved and quit to menu, set the game language to English, started back up again, looked at the list, and went; Ohhh! Duh, a rubber bushing! Why didn't you just SAY so? I KNOW those! (And I know the name of that part mainly from watching YouTube videos of HotRod Magazine/HotRod Garage, and reading those kind of magazines - in English. For about 70% of the parts, I have NO clue what they are by the Dutch names alone)How simplified is it under the hood? Well, all cars have similar parts, for one. A front suspension has a crossmember, shocks, springs, a swaybar and end links, steering rack with inner and outer tie rods, upper and/or lower control arms, wheel knuckle housing, wheel hub, brake disk, pads, and a brake caliper. All but one or two cars come with a brake servo, and the newer models with an ABS pump and control unit. Brake lines? Nope. Brake fluid? Nope. A need to bleed the system after you rebuilt it? Nope.The engines? Let's stick with my favorite type of cars; the old ones. There's several classics that are all too recognizable; a 1957 Chevy Bel Air, a 1969 Ford Mustang, a 1968 Chevrolet Chevelle, a 1969 Dodge Charger. Of course they are not called that; the game has given each car its own brand and type. Big plus; they have actually taken the time to design logos and name badges that are on the cars, and they look good, too!But, the engines. Those four cars I mentioned all come with a carburated overhead-cam V8 engine. All parts are interchangeable, except for the two-carb intake manifold that comes on the Mustang. Have you bought a Chevelle and want to spruce it up a bit with a dual carburetor setup? Sorry, no can do, that dual-carb intake manifold is not an optional part for that car. Even when you take the V8 out of a Mustang and put it in the Chevelle, you can only put on the single-carb intake manifold. The only optional parts you can change on a car are the rims, and body parts if you have the Visual Tuning DLC pack.For the rest, though, it's good. Quite simplified, but with plenty of detail parts even so. Take apart one of those old V8's, and you find yourself with a box full of individual rocker arms and pushrods which you can take out one by one - and there's sixteen of them in one engine.There's one big drawback, though. You can't take the whole engine plus transmission out of the car in one big lump and put it on an engine stand to disassemble it, like almost any car restorer does; you have to disassemble, and reassemble it, in the car. And some parts you can only reach from underneath. Once you have gotten down to the engine block, it's; take out pistons, lift car, get under, remove oil pan (if you already hadn't), remove crankshaft caps, remove crankshaft, get out, lower car, remove engine block. Fix up or buy new one. Put in engine block, lift car, get under, put in crankshaft, put in crankshaft caps, get out, lower car, put in pistons, lift car, get under, put on oil pan and filter, get out, lower car, rebuild rest of the engine. That would be SO much easier if you could just take the whole thing out, put it on an engine stand, and disassemble/reassemble there.And the simplification shows. The plug wires are the only wires you'll find in the whole car. The detailing goes as far as to put individual clips on the air filter box/distributor cap you have to take off, but a wiring loom for all the electrics? Not there. Gaskets? Not there. There's a fuel filter, but fuel lines? Nope. Brake lines? Nope. And even on the most hashed-out rusty wreck of a 1957 Bel Air you buy at the auction house, ALL the bolts are always brand new. The rims and parts of the suspension/engine may be so rusted they are beyond repair, but they still come off with three turns of your wrench on the brand new bolts holding everything in place.The same goes for the fixing of the parts. You have a work table where you can fix a good number of the parts you take off a car. Butthe fixing process is; click. You managed to repair the part! Condition is now X%! Or; click. You failed to repair the part. Condition has decreased. (and it always decreases to a point so low you can't re-attempt to fix it again. So if you hash up a part, it's utterly broken and you need to buy a new one)Still, overall, it's a great game. After 100 hours I'm still not bored of it, even if I'm doing pretty much the same things over and over again. It just has that certain something about it that keeps drawing you in to play it more. There's just a few little things that could make it even better.- placing of the oil drain pan. That is SUCH a hit-and-miss, because you can't look upwards properly once you're moving that thing around. I end up just removing the oil pan and taking the $100 fine for oil cleanup, rather than to fiddle around with that drain and having it sit just a smidge too far to the left, right, front or back anyway.- disassembling/reassembling the engine outside of the car on an angine stand. If that could be implemented, it would be SUCH an improvement.- customizing of the cars. Currently, it's just visual with body parts and head/tail lights and bumpers, and rims, and only when you have the Visual Tuning DLC pack. If you were allowed to put different engines in different cars, or even do things like put that dual-carb intake on a single-carb V8 engine, that would make things a lot more fun. Also, speed parts would be nice. Take the tame little Pinto, yank out that four-banger engine, plop in a V8 with a high-lift cam, dual or triple carburetors and a turbo or a blower, and you suddenly have a much more interesting car.- graphics. Not the overall game graphics; those are pretty good as is. But some extra graphics for the cars? That would be a lot more fun. Take the Dodge Charger, give it a new paint job, and let us put on a bumblebee stripe around the rear end, for instance. Or racing stripes over the hood and trunk of the Chevelle. Or a spiffy flame-job. Hell yeah.- the test drive. Currently, there are in fact different engine sounds for the different cars, and some different driving characteristics. But the handling is atrocious, and the whole thing feels a bit... tacked on. Almost like it was an afterthought. There is massive potential for improvement there.- bodywork on the cars. At the moment, it's front bumper, headlights, hood, front fenders, doors, trunk lid, taillights, rear bumper. Not even windshields/rear windows/side windows (and everyone who ever restored an old car knows that the quarter panels/rear fenders and floor pans are 90% of the time the areas that need the most work). I can see a lot of potential for improvement there as well, the outer bodywork, and the interior as well. Allow us to put in leather bucket seats, for instance, or give the interior a different color than black.Do I recommend this game though? Hell yes!

Posted: August 23, 2016
												I was dubious about this game. There's a vast amount of Simulator titled games out there and from the title, this doesn't sound like it's one of the more interesting ones. In the end, I think it was a sale that enticed me in and I'm glad I did, there's gameplay to be had here.You don't necessarily get dropped in at the deep end, you start off only being able to access the more simple jobs. I know how a car works and how it's bolted together so unfortunately I can't comment on how easy this is for those totally new to it all. It's reasonably realistic though, so if you're picking it up you're learning something!The initial pace is a little slow and a bit 'grindy' in places. Once you've unlocked everything though there's a few ways you can play it. I've taken to buying cars at auction and completely rebuilding them to see how much profit is available in each model. There's a few other strategies I've not tried yet such as only replacing parts less than 80%.Eventually, you'll realise that all you're doing is giving the mouse some exercise as you're just clicking the same things over and over again. When that happens, you can switch the brain back on and take on a few customer jobs instead, requiring you to investigate things. I'm not sure how much life is left in the game, but I've had over 60 hours in it so far so I've gotten my moneys worth.

Posted: March 31
												Car Mechanic Simulator (henceforth CMS) 2015 is a distinct improvement over what was offered with CMS 2014. The fact that you can choose what jobs to accept or decline is very nice, especially as you are starting out and may not know where a particular problem might lie. However, where I think this game really shines is being able to buy a heap for cheap, gut it, repair what parts you are able, replace the rest, and sell it for a tidy profit. You may also elect to keep it for yourself, but there is little to do with it if you do, other than to simply look at it. My recommendation to any new players of the game is to do enough jobs to save up a bit of money, then start buying and fixing up cars from the auction. You can bet that the price of the car is going to double or triple in the auction house, and I would say to save up enough money to possibly double THAT amount before you start fixing things up. Until you really level up your repair skill (something I would definitely focus on fairly early on), you'll probably need to buy parts to replace all of the ones that you fail to repair. All of that aside, here is how I would evaluate the game:The Good:- Fixing up old cars and selling them is fantastic. This is where this game shines, and the enjoyment of this outweighs all of the negative points of this game put together. At the time of this review, I have clocked a little over 30 hours on the game, and I periodically return to it simply to do this. Although a little unrealistic, it's very satisfying to take something that's absolute garbage and get it into like-new condition, and there is a hefty bonus for selling a car that is in 100% condition.- Leveling up your skills as a mechanic is now separate from money, which you will be needing for the purchase of cars when you get tired of doing work orders.- Havng the garage means that you can hang onto a car that you really like, and it can be expanded with plenty of space for you to collect them all.- Fixing parts is free, but it has the possibility of breaking them, as well. This means that many jobs can be done quite cheaply, and this further increases the potential for profit in selling cars.- The game looks very nice and runs smoothly, at least on my computer.- The core gameplay of removing and replacing parts is executed well, and most things are pretty efficient, although it would be nice to have a side-by-side for your inventory and the shop.The Bad:- There is very little to do with cars once they are fixed up, other than sell them or send them to the garage. However, I don't really like driving or racing games, so this has little bearing on my opinion of the game.- Accessibility of parts is kind of an issue. Even if you are doing things in the most efficient way possible, you have to use the lift multiple times to get at every single part. The worst culprit by far is the crankshaft (and, by extension, the engine block). You have to use the lift once to remove the oil pan and the pieces keeping the crankshaft in place, another time to remove the pistons (and any other engine parts required to get at them), and once more to get the crankshaft out. Then, if you need to get at the engine block itself, it's a FOURTH go on the lift to get it out once the crankshaft has been removed. This is all a pretty minor gripe at the end of the day, and it may be fairly realistic, but it's still kind of annoying.- Even with the convenience of the PDA, which makes it so that you can buy parts without having to run back to your desk, the shop menu is separate from your inventory screen. This means that it can be cumbersome to buy a lot of parts to replace those that you have broken when fixing up an old junker.- Collecting oil requires you to be a sniper. Don't bother with it. Just pay the $100 cleanup fee.- Parts that you are repairing break quite often. When fully leveled, you have a 90% chance to repair a part, but you do not FULLY repair it. This means that you roll those dice multiple times per part. They really should've had a decrease in condition by a random amount if that 10% chance comes up, but instead, the thing is totally borked. So if you have a part that is in poor condition so that you need to hit "repair" 4 times to get it fully to 100%, then you actually have a chance that is 90%*90%*90%*90%, or about 66% chance of getting it fully repaired and 34% chance of breaking it entirely and paying to replace it. That may not sound bad, but that is what it is like when you're at max level. - DLC. Gross. Well, it's not AWFUL, but here's the thing: the "Gold" version of this game only includes some of the DLC. Most of the rest of it adds actual brand name vehicles to the lineup. So, since they have to pay to use those brands, it makes some sense. Even so, it leaves a bitter taste in my mouth to buy the Gold version and not even get the majority of the DLC.The Ugly:- The game actually looks very nice on the whole, but the textures for new parts sometimes doesn't say "shiny chrome" so much as it does "plastic thing painted to look like shiny chrome."- Some of the paint colors are pretty awful.... well, just like with real-life cars, truthfully. Many of them are quite nice, but it seems like you're more likely to wind up with something pretty ugly. You can paint them a new color, but you really can't preview a car's color very well in the paint shop without paying to have it painted, which means that tweaking that color can get kinda expensive.

Posted: August 12, 2016
Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 (CMS 15) is exactly what is sounds like: a car mechanic simulator. The player takes the role of a mechanic in your very own garage. As you build up a good reputation and learn more, you get to work on harder, more complex vehicles. You are given hints early on to help you determine exactly what parts to fix or replace, but soon those nice yellow outlines will disappear, and you're on your own. Cars get nicer, and so do your payouts.Car Mechanic Sim is literally all I hoped it to be. I wanted to learn more about how cars come together, and it did the job perfectly for me. While it's not a 100% accurate simulation, the game does a good job of giving you the gist of certain aspects of how a car works. Before playing CMS15, I wouldn't have known how suspension even works in cars. I really like working on older cars, such as muscle cars and other little classic cars, because of how different they are from modern designs, especially the engines and the suspension setups.ProsGood basic learning toolLots of inexpensive DLCs to expand the gameplay (licensed brands, tuning options)Good array of cars parodied from real-world vehicles.ConsNot a full car simulation! It's a mechanic sim!Gets progressively more difficult (could be interpreted either way really, just putting it in the cons because it has more weight as a con) The gameplay is a bit repetitive after a while. You may like to try the challenge mode to mix things up a bit!Final Thoughts:CMS is a good way to pass time and learn something while doing it!Rating: 9.0/10This review was written for and is published on the  Lit Reviews [LR] curator page.

Posted: September 13, 2016
												Overall I really enjoy this game. I really feel like this is a spiritual successor to a much older game that some car enthusiasts might be familiar with ("Gearhead Garage"). There are a lot of welcome improvements over the 2014 version of the game such as the ability to buy cars from the auction and sell them. The variety of cars is good and I like how there is an actual variety of how you assemble the vehicles. The graphics are pretty nice. Some of the game modes such as the test track and the paint booth seem a little underdeveloped in my opinion (as in the steering is a little difficult and the paint booth is pretty simplistic in terms of color choice.) The DLCs are pretty reasonably priced for the content in them. The only two things that bother me to any extent in the game is that you have to put a LOT of time into the game before you are able to access the auction block. I feel like the real highlight of the game is the ability to buy cars in various condition at the auction and then fix them up to sell them. Along with the auction sequence comes my second issue with the game: you should be able to put the car up for auction as opposed to outright selling it, and the work order screen should have some information on how much of a total monetary and time investment you have in the car.  With those things said, I don't think that they interfere with my enjoyment of the game to the extent that I would quit playing it or that I wouldn't recommend it.I bought the game as a bundle with a lot of its DLC included. I would buy it again. I would recommend it to others that are interested in cars and simulation games.

Posted: April 1
												Fantastic game.I really enjoyed playing this one, my friend had this on his account and I had a go and ended up playing it for 10 hours over a couple of days and had to purchase it. I like cars irl and know a small ammount about mechanics and the simulator is a great way of learning some of the basic parts of a car and get a rough idea of where everything goes. However, it isn't realistic in that you would be able to take the knowledge to the real thing, although any hobbyist mechanic may find some use for this.Away from the eduactional side of things and on to the gameplay. The game is really fun at first but it does start to grind on whilst you raise your level and gain enough money to hit the auctions. However, once you have done this grind it will be well worth it because the game so much more interesting and fun when you can buy old bangers and suke them up into high powered machines to either race around or sell for a high profit.One of my favorite games.Pro'sReally well designed and easy to learnHelps learning names and places of actual car partsGood end game contentHighly replayableNice graphicsAwesome soundtrackCon'sSome of the DLC seems rather overpriced for what it addsProbably extremely boring if you have no interest in cars or mechanicsI highly recomend this game to anyone with an interest in cars/mechanics but I would say that if you don't have much interest try a demo or something first as my friend who owns this finds it really dull.

Posted: October 29, 2016
												As someone who really works on cars, I'd say this is a failry accurate mechanic sim without the grazed knuckles and frustration of hard to get to bolts.Very similar to games such as Gearhead Garage and Street Legal, this game puts you in charge of your own workshop. You make money fixing customers cars which you can then spend on buying cars at auction. The auction cars always need some work, when the work is complete you can either add the car to your garage, or sell it for a profit.I am restoring a DeLorean in real life so I also grabbed the DeLorean DLC. It's pretty accurate, although some things in the engine bay are in the wrong place and the DeLorean in this game has a power steering pump instead of an A/C unit, but I understand this is probably a limitation of the game engine. It did feel weird taking the mix unit and intake manifold off to inspect the Valley of Death as I have done on my own DeLorean.I've had hours of fun, the only downside to the game is it can get repetitive. quite a lot of the customer jobs are big jobs such as rebuilding the entire front and back suspension system, which is time consuming and monotonous. Having said that, life as a real mechanic would be very similar. There is also not much you can do with your own cars once they have been rebuilt, apart from sit in them or take them around a test track.Overall I'd recommend this game to anyone who has an interest in pulling cars and engines to bits and at the moment this is probably THE best game on the market for anyone wanting a modern Gearhead Garage clone.

Posted: December 27, 2015
												A must have for a car nut! I love the game. I have worked on cars before and mostly everything is spot on - especially suspension wise. There are some parts that have either been omitted or overly simplified but - especially engine wise - but it's no big deal. It performs well but has a few weird quirks. I could not get the game to load until a user suggested I force-minimize the game via CTRL+ALT+DEL, then go back in, which oddly enough worked out.PROS:- Fun and educational- Very accurate parts wise- Great visuals- Nice testing tools- Good experience points and unlocks- Nice soundtrack (in my opinion)CONS:- Odd performance quirks at times- Long and frequent loading times- Some overly simplified engine components- Camera fights with you sometimesSUGGESTIONS FOR CMS 2016:- Let's get deeper into engine parts! I realize it might turn away some folks because engines can get very complex. Perhaps a difficulty setting where this is adjustable?- Automatic transmissions. Every car in this game is a manual. Autos would be nice as they would introduce a whole new category of drivetrains.- The aftermarket scene. I realize this is probably a can of worms, but a few performance mods wouldn't hurt. It's not uncommon for people to take their cars to shops and request performance parts. Throw in a dyno too!

Posted: October 7, 2015
												The first time I played this I burned through almost five hours of doing repairs. After a few days of playing it I'm starting to find it a little routine simply because I've gotten nearly all the experience perks that are available, and there's only 5 or 6 different models of vehicles that I've gotten to work on. The best part of the game is the detective work, it makes the player think of where to look for problems and gives them tools to diagnose them. Early on you may be tempted to just rip apart the whole engine and put it all back in piece by piece (I've done it). That method works, but the game doesn't penalize you for the time it takes. Since the pieces are rudamentary an engine can be broken down to it's components inside of three RL minutes.In the future I hope that the developers incorporate a timer to dole out experience or money based on how quickly you diagnosed and solved a problem. Ultimately I think I'll just get sick of looking at the same 60-70 parts and doing the same repairs over and over and lose interest, which is a shame because with some ingenuity and integration this could be a very long-lived and entertaining sim:Motor bikes, company finances, hiring/firing AI staff to help on other cars, negotiating repair estimates, having something to do with the pile of junk you yank off cars, even a leveling and story mode are all things that could make me play this game a lot more frequently and for a longer time. Don't get me wrong, still very promising and even educational experience.All in all, it's a great sim with a ton of potential and I'm really looking forward to seeing what direction it goes in. Reccomended, but sincerely hoping for more content to keep it interesting.

Posted: June 24, 2015
												Vastly improved over CMS 2014. Graphics are much nicer and the engines/vehicles look much closer to their real life counterparts, though there are still a few mistakes. Wider variety of vehicles and a larger garage enables multiple jobs simultaenously.The ability to purchase cars at aution and restore them either for profit or your personal collection is very welcome. The only complaints I have about the auction house are that each car gets sent to your parking lot automatically and there is a set number of cars per auction. I do understand that the limited number of cars is more realistic but it is rather bothersome when I am looking for a specific car to work on. The issue with sending cars to the parking lot is understandable and would be more bearable if the loading times were lower.I also really liked the addition of diagnostic tools and a leveling system not based on cash. The only complaint in that department is that the repair skill maxes out at 90%. That is literally my one complaint about the new system. Everything else was a welcome change.The developer also seems to be pushing updates regularly (as of July, 2015) which is much appreciated. Several patches were already released since I purchased this game. More vehicles and tuning parts have also been added as optional DLC.

Posted: June 27, 2015
												There's good and bad, but overall, it's a worthwhile and entertaining game. The bad: Some things I found irritating was the whole "Repair Bench" system. For the most part you can repair most parts on it, and depending how  many points you have spent in the skill, you have up to a 90% chance of repairing a part. However there seems to be no rhyme or reason to which parts you can or cannot repair. For example, you can somehow repair brake shoes, but not brake discs. Another problem is with the repairs itself... As mentioned, you have up to a 90% chance of a successful repair if you purchase all the points for the repair bench. That may seem like a lot, however given that it may take up to 5 repairs on say an engine block, you really only have a 5 out of 9 chance of completely repairing it successfully. This means you may repair an expensive item up to 89% or so, but then fail your last roll and completely destroy it. How does that happen in real life? I have an almost brand new engine and somehow I totally ruin it beyond repair? I could understand letting it only repair up to a certain point, but the way the system works, even with full points in repair, you end up ruining more than half the parts you pull on any given repair job. Also... how the hell difficult is it to put an oil pan under the engine to avoid a $100 spill.The good: It's fun... But gets old fast. Not a lot of variety. Most cars are different only on the outside. If you've worked on one, you've worked on them all.

Posted: September 5, 2016
												 Fist and foremost this game is a fun game and does teach about basic auto mechanics and theory. now that schools do not teach my favorite subject in high school. I recommend this game to up and coming moter heads. That being said I was dissappointed in no real use of tools. I had hoped to open the toolchesy and see all of the automotive tools of the trade. I think the company that made this game could approach snapon tools and be able to have their sponsership and the snapon brand name all over the toolsets and shops. Since this is the future autoshop class for teaching beginning motorheads, imagine have to use the right tools on the right bolts, the cursor turning into the tool, metric and standard sockets, torque wrenches and their settings, bolt tightning order. Since this game is a problem solving game it would be another level of problem solving. right now it is the removal order and assembly order. in the real world is the the right tool for the right job. for instance a disk brake caliper fails with its seals, the brake dissasembly detail is lacking especially in the drum type brakes, keppers, self adjuster, and parking brake arm to say the least is missing. The biggest offence I found in this game was that the piston is removed from the top, there is no unbolting the connecting rod cap from the bottom to remove the piston from the top. I see that with the DLC more detail is being done to the engines, again if the company that made this game would probably be able to get the cad data for all the ford line or cheve line of engines if the advertised those cars in the game. I am a digital artist by trade and have done many different car engines and cars for the major car manufactures. this is my list for 2016 auto machanic.1.Tools used for the various parts, you can start with the basic toolbox and get more snapon tools with experience points. specialty tools for specialty jobs. for body rapair all the different tools for that too.2.Transmission shop, where you can dissasemble and rebuild many different transmission types.3.Engine rebuild shop where you can take the worn out engines and rebore them, or resleeve them, rework the connecting rods, regrind valves, all the things an engine rebuilder does.4.More detailed, brake repair, sterring repair including power steering, rack and pinion, steering box repair.5. The whole nightmare of electrical repair, one of the most elusive repairs to auto machanic.6. Another nightmare of the cars vacume system.All of this to me would make a better simulation experience. To an already fun game to play.I am recommending this game to anybody who has no clue to basic repair theories. This is a great start to learning the ins and outs of how cars work.Buy this game so they will continue to make it better.I look forward to the next release.

Posted: September 20, 2016
												Just started to play the game. First time running the game there was no overlay or text on screen. Restart fixed this. Game seems pretty cool if you have ever taken apart a car before. It IS pretty realistic having to remove certain components before you can get to the part you are trying to fix/replace. The actual bolts do leave alot to be desired though. For instance when taking off a brake caliper there is no slide, boot, need to grease or brush/sand/grind. I realize this may be beyond the scope of the game/sim but the more realistic the better. People could actually learn something! Including me! I am no pro mechanic and im sure there is alot myself and others can learn from it. Overall so far I think its a pretty good start for this type of sim and im sure, in time, it will get even better and more realistic. I will be checking it out more.

Posted: September 15, 2016
												Fun game if you have an interest in cars and car mechanics.The game looks and feels great - you never feel like you're battling a crummy UI or awkward camera. Stripping parts is neither fast nor slow - gives the sense that you're tearing a machine down, rather than just automagically removing everything - this is always going to be hard to balance just right but I think the game gets as close as it needs to.The only thing I've found that I wish I could do is make recommendations to the customer. As it is every job has a minimum wear level - so any parts below a certain wear need to be replaced.  A good example of where I'd like this to work differently is if I'm doing a brake job and am replacing 3 brake pads - in reality this would never happen, you'd replace them all, even if the 4th isn't particularly worn.I don't really rate the driving aspects of the game - but it's not why I bought it so I can overlook it, and once you get the test path you don't really need to drive the cars anyway. If you're looking for a game more like Street Legal Racing then you might be dissapointed though.

Posted: November 10, 2015
												I wouldn't call this game "fun" per se (though it is) but instead, satisfying. As somebody who doesn't know much about wrenching cars, I've always envied friends of mine who were good at it. I'm not presuming this game has magically made me handy in the garage but I have learned a lot more than I knew before. I've even learned about cursing at a car in which I forgot some critical piece after a long re-assemble. I was interested in the title but didn't really expect much. It's turned out to be one of the most satisfying games I've played in a long time. My compliments to the developers.

												I agree with alot of people, that this game is fun, accurate, and enjoyable. But there is some main components missing from the game. Posted: December 2, 2015
												So. Car Mechanic Simulator 2015. The year is almost over, and I have a good 100 hours on this game, so it's about time for a review.What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said? It's definitely a very good game, it's informative in its own way, educational, and just plain fun, especially when you save up enough money and experience to expand your garage, get the paint shop, get the underground parking, and go to the auction house to buy wrecks you can fix up and sell for a profit.Of course, things are simplified a lot under the hood of each car you get to work on. I'm no mechanic, but I know enough of cars to have done maintenance on my own cars, and I have studied a lot of stuff for stories I write in which a character is an actual mechanic. There is in fact a funny thing about that; the game showed me painfully well how I got most of my knowledge about cars. It started in Dutch, as that is the language set on my laptop, and one of the first customer cars I got in showed a list that said there was a part that needed replacing. And I was all like; what the hell is that? So I saved and quit to menu, set the game language to English, started back up again, looked at the list, and went; Ohhh! Duh, a rubber bushing! Why didn't you just SAY so? I KNOW those! (And I know the name of that part mainly from watching YouTube videos of HotRod Magazine/HotRod Garage, and reading those kind of magazines - in English. For about 70% of the parts, I have NO clue what they are by the Dutch names alone)How simplified is it under the hood? Well, all cars have similar parts, for one. A front suspension has a crossmember, shocks, springs, a swaybar and end links, steering rack with inner and outer tie rods, upper and/or lower control arms, wheel knuckle housing, wheel hub, brake disk, pads, and a brake caliper. All but one or two cars come with a brake servo, and the newer models with an ABS pump and control unit. Brake lines? Nope. Brake fluid? Nope. A need to bleed the system after you rebuilt it? Nope.The engines? Let's stick with my favorite type of cars; the old ones. There's several classics that are all too recognizable; a 1957 Chevy Bel Air, a 1969 Ford Mustang, a 1968 Chevrolet Chevelle, a 1969 Dodge Charger. Of course they are not called that; the game has given each car its own brand and type. Big plus; they have actually taken the time to design logos and name badges that are on the cars, and they look good, too!But, the engines. Those four cars I mentioned all come with a carburated overhead-cam V8 engine. All parts are interchangeable, except for the two-carb intake manifold that comes on the Mustang. Have you bought a Chevelle and want to spruce it up a bit with a dual carburetor setup? Sorry, no can do, that dual-carb intake manifold is not an optional part for that car. Even when you take the V8 out of a Mustang and put it in the Chevelle, you can only put on the single-carb intake manifold. The only optional parts you can change on a car are the rims, and body parts if you have the Visual Tuning DLC pack.For the rest, though, it's good. Quite simplified, but with plenty of detail parts even so. Take apart one of those old V8's, and you find yourself with a box full of individual rocker arms and pushrods which you can take out one by one - and there's sixteen of them in one engine.There's one big drawback, though. You can't take the whole engine plus transmission out of the car in one big lump and put it on an engine stand to disassemble it, like almost any car restorer does; you have to disassemble, and reassemble it, in the car. And some parts you can only reach from underneath. Once you have gotten down to the engine block, it's; take out pistons, lift car, get under, remove oil pan (if you already hadn't), remove crankshaft caps, remove crankshaft, get out, lower car, remove engine block. Fix up or buy new one. Put in engine block, lift car, get under, put in crankshaft, put in crankshaft caps, get out, lower car, put in pistons, lift car, get under, put on oil pan and filter, get out, lower car, rebuild rest of the engine. That would be SO much easier if you could just take the whole thing out, put it on an engine stand, and disassemble/reassemble there.And the simplification shows. The plug wires are the only wires you'll find in the whole car. The detailing goes as far as to put individual clips on the air filter box/distributor cap you have to take off, but a wiring loom for all the electrics? Not there. Gaskets? Not there. There's a fuel filter, but fuel lines? Nope. Brake lines? Nope. And even on the most hashed-out rusty wreck of a 1957 Bel Air you buy at the auction house, ALL the bolts are always brand new. The rims and parts of the suspension/engine may be so rusted they are beyond repair, but they still come off with three turns of your wrench on the brand new bolts holding everything in place.The same goes for the fixing of the parts. You have a work table where you can fix a good number of the parts you take off a car. Butthe fixing process is; click. You managed to repair the part! Condition is now X%! Or; click. You failed to repair the part. Condition has decreased. (and it always decreases to a point so low you can't re-attempt to fix it again. So if you hash up a part, it's utterly broken and you need to buy a new one)Still, overall, it's a great game. After 100 hours I'm still not bored of it, even if I'm doing pretty much the same things over and over again. It just has that certain something about it that keeps drawing you in to play it more. There's just a few little things that could make it even better.- placing of the oil drain pan. That is SUCH a hit-and-miss, because you can't look upwards properly once you're moving that thing around. I end up just removing the oil pan and taking the $100 fine for oil cleanup, rather than to fiddle around with that drain and having it sit just a smidge too far to the left, right, front or back anyway.- disassembling/reassembling the engine outside of the car on an angine stand. If that could be implemented, it would be SUCH an improvement.- customizing of the cars. Currently, it's just visual with body parts and head/tail lights and bumpers, and rims, and only when you have the Visual Tuning DLC pack. If you were allowed to put different engines in different cars, or even do things like put that dual-carb intake on a single-carb V8 engine, that would make things a lot more fun. Also, speed parts would be nice. Take the tame little Pinto, yank out that four-banger engine, plop in a V8 with a high-lift cam, dual or triple carburetors and a turbo or a blower, and you suddenly have a much more interesting car.- graphics. Not the overall game graphics; those are pretty good as is. But some extra graphics for the cars? That would be a lot more fun. Take the Dodge Charger, give it a new paint job, and let us put on a bumblebee stripe around the rear end, for instance. Or racing stripes over the hood and trunk of the Chevelle. Or a spiffy flame-job. Hell yeah.- the test drive. Currently, there are in fact different engine sounds for the different cars, and some different driving characteristics. But the handling is atrocious, and the whole thing feels a bit... tacked on. Almost like it was an afterthought. There is massive potential for improvement there.- bodywork on the cars. At the moment, it's front bumper, headlights, hood, front fenders, doors, trunk lid, taillights, rear bumper. Not even windshields/rear windows/side windows (and everyone who ever restored an old car knows that the quarter panels/rear fenders and floor pans are 90% of the time the areas that need the most work). I can see a lot of potential for improvement there as well, the outer bodywork, and the interior as well. Allow us to put in leather bucket seats, for instance, or give the interior a different color than black.Do I recommend this game though? Hell yes!

												The game itself is well made (graphically, etc.), but skimping with different motor types and mechanical challenges (only 4 motorypes plus the "make no money Maluch"). Posted: December 5, 2015
												"Just one more car, then I'll sleep."I was lucky to catch this game during a Steam sale but would have been just as happy to pay full price. Nice graphics, no bugs or glitches that interrupt gameplay and, overall, it can be quite therapeutic (as long as you don't need to replace a crankshaft). Jobs become more difficult as you progress, requiring you to take advantage of upgrades and unlockable extensions for your garage to make life a little easier. Although some car parts can be a little hard to find, you don't need to be a petrol head to enjoy playing. 10/10, would recommend to anyone 16 or above.

Nope.The engines? Let's stick with my favorite type of cars; the old ones. There's several classics that are all too recognizable; a 1957 Chevy Bel Air, a 1969 Ford Mustang, a 1968 Chevrolet Chevelle, a 1969 Dodge Charger. Of course they are not called that; the game has given each car its own brand and type. Big plus; they have actually taken the time to design logos and name badges that are on the cars, and they look good, too!But, the engines. Those four cars I mentioned all come with a carburated overhead-cam V8 engine. All parts are interchangeable, except for the two-carb intake manifold that comes on the Mustang. Have you bought a Chevelle and want to spruce it up a bit with a dual carburetor setup? Sorry, no can do, that dual-carb intake manifold is not an optional part for that car. Even when you take the V8 out of a Mustang and put it in the Chevelle, you can only put on the single-carb intake manifold. The only optional parts you can change on a car are the rims, and body parts if you have the Visual Tuning DLC pack.For the rest, though, it's good. Quite simplified, but with plenty of detail parts even so. Take apart one of those old V8's, and you find yourself with a box full of individual rocker arms and pushrods which you can take out one by one - and there's sixteen of them in one engine.There's one big drawback, though. You can't take the whole engine plus transmission out of the car in one big lump and put it on an engine stand to disassemble it, like almost any car restorer does; you have to disassemble, and reassemble it, in the car. And some parts you can only reach from underneath. Once you have gotten down to the engine block, it's; take out pistons, lift car, get under, remove oil pan (if you already hadn't), remove crankshaft caps, remove crankshaft, get out, lower car, remove engine block. Fix up or buy new one. Put in engine block, lift car, get under, put in crankshaft, put in crankshaft caps, get out, lower car, put in pistons, lift car, get under, put on oil pan and filter, get out, lower car, rebuild rest of the engine. That would be SO much easier if you could just take the whole thing out, put it on an engine stand, and disassemble/reassemble there.And the simplification shows. The plug wires are the only wires you'll find in the whole car. The detailing goes as far as to put individual clips on the air filter box/distributor cap you have to take off, but a wiring loom for all the electrics? Not there. Gaskets? Not there. There's a fuel filter, but fuel lines? Nope. Brake lines? Nope. And even on the most hashed-out rusty wreck of a 1957 Bel Air you buy at the auction house, ALL the bolts are always brand new. The rims and parts of the suspension/engine may be so rusted they are beyond repair, but they still come off with three turns of your wrench on the brand new bolts holding everything in place.The same goes for the fixing of the parts. You have a work table where you can fix a good number of the parts you take off a car. Butthe fixing process is; click. You managed to repair the part! Condition is now X%! Or; click. You failed to repair the part. Condition has decreased. (and it always decreases to a point so low you can't re-attempt to fix it again. So if you hash up a part, it's utterly broken and you need to buy a new one)Still, overall, it's a great game. After 100 hours I'm still not bored of it, even if I'm doing pretty much the same things over and over again. It just has that certain something about it that keeps drawing you in to play it more. There's just a few little things that could make it even better.- placing of the oil drain pan. That is SUCH a hit-and-miss, because you can't look upwards properly once you're moving that thing around. I end up just removing the oil pan and taking the $100 fine for oil cleanup, rather than to fiddle around with that drain and having it sit just a smidge too far to the left, right, front or back anyway.- disassembling/reassembling the engine outside of the car on an angine stand. If that could be implemented, it would be SUCH an improvement.- customizing of the cars. Currently, it's just visual with body parts and head/tail lights and bumpers, and rims, and only when you have the Visual Tuning DLC pack. If you were allowed to put different engines in different cars, or even do things like put that dual-carb intake on a single-carb V8 engine, that would make things a lot more fun. Also, speed parts would be nice. Take the tame little Pinto, yank out that four-banger engine, plop in a V8 with a high-lift cam, dual or triple carburetors and a turbo or a blower, and you suddenly have a much more interesting car.- graphics. Not the overall game graphics; those are pretty good as is. But some extra graphics for the cars? That would be a lot more fun. Take the Dodge Charger, give it a new paint job, and let us put on a bumblebee stripe around the rear end, for instance. Or racing stripes over the hood and trunk of the Chevelle. Or a spiffy flame-job. Hell yeah.- the test drive. Currently, there are in fact different engine sounds for the different cars, and some different driving characteristics. But the handling is atrocious, and the whole thing feels a bit... tacked on. Almost like it was an afterthought. There is massive potential for improvement there.- bodywork on the cars. At the moment, it's front bumper, headlights, hood, front fenders, doors, trunk lid, taillights, rear bumper. Not even windshields/rear windows/side windows (and everyone who ever restored an old car knows that the quarter panels/rear fenders and floor pans are 90% of the time the areas that need the most work). I can see a lot of potential for improvement there as well, the outer bodywork, and the interior as well. Allow us to put in leather bucket seats, for instance, or give the interior a different color than black.Do I recommend this game though? Hell yes!

Posted: March 24
												This game is a massive improvement to CMS14 in every meaningful way, and will help to quickly fill in the gaps to your car knowledge. As with any simulator, there is only so far that you can go to make it feel like the real thing, but in terms of interactive, consumer-grade media, this is probably the best thing on the market right now.The game can get a little repetitive at times, but I'm sure being an actual car mechanic gets a little repetetive too, particularly if you were to specialize in a limited field (like Japanese import transmissions, etc.). This game allows you to work on all aspects of a car, and for the most part, you can strip the cars down to the bone. The upgrade system is kind of a grind, but overall the pacing feels right. If you start a traditional game, the vehicles will have lists of the parts that need replacing, which can be highlighted on the car and identified easily. Over time, the lists will start to identify fewer and fewer parts, and force you to have to search for them and inspect manually. The projects themselves also become increasingly complicated. This system feels like it's rewarding your learning, and it's an empowering feeling. In general I detest the business model in games nowadays -- especially from major studios/publishers -- that basically forces you to buy 'modules' in the form of DLC that should have been included at launch by default. This game does that, but doesn't feel like you're being robbed either. You may only be interested in learning the SUV/Truck or an old Mini, so in that sense it works and makes sense here. In this setting. it doesn't subtract from the gameplay or force you to purchase the ending/continuation of the story, so I can't knock it too much.In a relatively limited timeframe, you will probably be able to name every single part on a car, regardless of the engine/vehicle type. If that is your goal, you can't miss this one. Can't wait to see what they do with the next iteration.

A few folks complain about it not being accurate or realistic, and it isn't, but it gives you a very general overview of how cars are put together and how to take them apart. If you're at all a gearhead, or at all enjoy tinkering, puzzle games, or relaxing games, then this is for you.

												Other people have said this before but this isn't really a sim. This is more of a puzzle game involving various car and engine parts. Currently, there's a Mercedes-Benz DLC that adds the 300 SL Gullwing and the 560 SEC. There are more real life cars to come, now that the developers acquired the license for Maserati. Can't wait!

Posted: June 9, 2016
												So much, yet so little..,First of all, I thoroughly enjoy this game, I really do. I find myself perpetually visiting the site in order to see what new features and DLCs are available to satisfy this newly created obsession of putting wonderful machines together in different ways that I could never hope to afford on a garbage man's salary.When I first purchased Car Mechanic Simulator 2015, it was one of those titles on my wishlist that I'd hoped would finally give me enough of that car-mod junkie fix I was looking for. My feelings might be mixed on that one though. I played a game called Street Legal Racing (Redline) for a while that allowed you to put some cars together, but was extremely limited without the plethora of User Mods available out there (unfortunately, they cause the game to crash as often as -insert expletive here). What it did do right however, was the customizeability, and a nod to the racing genre if you felt like pursuing the in-game "game".Ok, let's start with what CMS 2015 is not. It is not a "Need For Speed" clone, and that is Ok. As titillating as the prospect of racing a hard worked, hard earned car is around a fictional Nürburgring facsimile with 15 sirens blaring in the background, I am of the mind that even with a AAA budget, you can either do one thing or the other very well but not both. CMS 2015 focuses on the simulatory aspects of building up your virtual baby with a level of detail that pleases and surprises.You start out with a workshop and some car repair jobs to choose from. As you progress, you gain some cash and leveling points that you can spend on equipment and such. Without delving into too many details so as to stay on point, you get to purchase or fix different components ranging from the suspension to the engine and really get into the "nuts and bolts" of things. After 20 or so hours and a real sense of accomplishment, I felt myself wishing that I could get even further detail into the parts I was dealing with. I was satisfied with changing things like cylinder heads and screwing on the bolts, but I kind of felt like "where is the head gasket?" That pesky thing that once caused me an overdraft and a scolding from my manager for coming in late. Another thing I desperately wanted, was to take Mr. Bean's car and drop some American V8 muscle in it with 21 inch rims and a boeing wing for downforce. Unfortunately and inexplicably, you can't! It seems to me that the foundations of the game are solid enough to support this though and I do really hope to see something like this very soon. In conclusion, the aspects that are included are very well polished. The assortment of cars work as unique puzzles that need specific pieces to fit in the right order and give you a greater appreciation than the sum of their parts. Yet, more detailed problems can be fleshed out to create greater challenges, as well as interesting combinations that could increase the longevity of the game (not to mention better custom modding) by leaps and bounds.Either way, I want more!

												I bought this game as a backer on Kickstarter, and let me tell you money well spent. The first chance I got to play it I was up all night playing this. This is crazy addictive if you are into the mechanics of a car. The auction is probably a favorite for me. Buy the rust bucket, strip it down completely, refurbish or buy new parts, spray it any color you want, test drive it, and just keeps going. You get experience as you are taking each piece off, granted it\'s only 1 XP per part, but you use that experience to gain upgrades to how fast you unbolt/bolt parts together, disassemble, a tablet so you don\'t have to keep running back to the computer, and a few other things. You also use this experience to unlock new areas of the shop. You gain money for completing a job order, use that and the experience to unlock parts of the shop. The money is also good to gain for cars at the auction, when you\'re experienced enough you can get yourself a parking garage to store your cars. The DLC\'s add such a great taste to it for all types of gearheads out there, whether you are into sporty cars or muscles, maybe even trucks. They thought of everyone when making the DLC\'s for this game. Granted there are no name brand vehicles for legal reasons I assume. Still, the cars are nice. I highly recommend this game, it\'s real addicting.

Posted: March 1, 2016
												I bought this game mostly for educational purposes. It was sometimes a shame to talk to a car mechanic and have no idea what he was talking about. So I wanted to get a bit of basic knoweledge of how is car made and what car mechanic really does. I must admit that this worked quite fine. Now I know where fuel pump is, how is clutch installed and that a good mechanic can literaly tear the engine apart taking out even pistons.Apart from that this game is really fun to play. You can see different concepts between modern cars and oldtimers. To not get you bored you can unlock some more features like possbility to paint cars or buy cars on auctions. Unfortunately even with these features the game quite quickly becomes repetitive.What really the game lacks is the feel of running your own workshop. It seems you do all the stuff buy yourself but there is no real economical model. You have unlimited number of orders, if you buy car parts you get them instantly, there are no factors like time or costs of failrues. You don't compete with other enterpreises, nobody cares if you are good or not.What I would really like to see is a model where dissasembly of a single part takes some time which is limited in a day. This would promote one to look for most obvious solutions rather than dissasemling the whole engine and looking randomly at the parts. I would like to have to wait several days (or weeks) for the parts I order, therefore I would have to run a storage in which I would keep most common parts to have them instantly and a parking with limited space for my orders. Time should be money, so you should be better paid for quicker repairs. I would like to have the possibility to estimate the price of repair to the customer and inform him next day that I was wrong and ask for his decision. I would like to have the possibility to hire other mechanics to do some work I got bored with myself. They game will not punish you for doing stupid things like - when you change the brake pad in one wheel you should change it in the other one even if its fine. Game only checks if a part is above requested realibility threshold and then it's considered correct. When you take of the pistons you would at least need to change the seals but in this game you can just install them back without any other costs. In oder words you are not punished by uneffective work at all.This game has a great potential which unfortunately was overlooked by the developers. They made a good game while they could make a perfect simulation. I still recommend this game if you want to learn some basics about the cars, but keep in mind that apart from dissasembling and assembling there is really no more depth inside and you migh get bored quite quickly.

Posted: March 31
												Car Mechanic Simulator (henceforth CMS) 2015 is a distinct improvement over what was offered with CMS 2014. The fact that you can choose what jobs to accept or decline is very nice, especially as you are starting out and may not know where a particular problem might lie. However, where I think this game really shines is being able to buy a heap for cheap, gut it, repair what parts you are able, replace the rest, and sell it for a tidy profit. You may also elect to keep it for yourself, but there is little to do with it if you do, other than to simply look at it. My recommendation to any new players of the game is to do enough jobs to save up a bit of money, then start buying and fixing up cars from the auction. You can bet that the price of the car is going to double or triple in the auction house, and I would say to save up enough money to possibly double THAT amount before you start fixing things up. Until you really level up your repair skill (something I would definitely focus on fairly early on), you'll probably need to buy parts to replace all of the ones that you fail to repair. All of that aside, here is how I would evaluate the game:The Good:- Fixing up old cars and selling them is fantastic. This is where this game shines, and the enjoyment of this outweighs all of the negative points of this game put together. At the time of this review, I have clocked a little over 30 hours on the game, and I periodically return to it simply to do this. Although a little unrealistic, it's very satisfying to take something that's absolute garbage and get it into like-new condition, and there is a hefty bonus for selling a car that is in 100% condition.- Leveling up your skills as a mechanic is now separate from money, which you will be needing for the purchase of cars when you get tired of doing work orders.- Havng the garage means that you can hang onto a car that you really like, and it can be expanded with plenty of space for you to collect them all.- Fixing parts is free, but it has the possibility of breaking them, as well. This means that many jobs can be done quite cheaply, and this further increases the potential for profit in selling cars.- The game looks very nice and runs smoothly, at least on my computer.- The core gameplay of removing and replacing parts is executed well, and most things are pretty efficient, although it would be nice to have a side-by-side for your inventory and the shop.The Bad:- There is very little to do with cars once they are fixed up, other than sell them or send them to the garage. However, I don't really like driving or racing games, so this has little bearing on my opinion of the game.- Accessibility of parts is kind of an issue. Even if you are doing things in the most efficient way possible, you have to use the lift multiple times to get at every single part. The worst culprit by far is the crankshaft (and, by extension, the engine block). You have to use the lift once to remove the oil pan and the pieces keeping the crankshaft in place, another time to remove the pistons (and any other engine parts required to get at them), and once more to get the crankshaft out. Then, if you need to get at the engine block itself, it's a FOURTH go on the lift to get it out once the crankshaft has been removed. This is all a pretty minor gripe at the end of the day, and it may be fairly realistic, but it's still kind of annoying.- Even with the convenience of the PDA, which makes it so that you can buy parts without having to run back to your desk, the shop menu is separate from your inventory screen. This means that it can be cumbersome to buy a lot of parts to replace those that you have broken when fixing up an old junker.- Collecting oil requires you to be a sniper. Don't bother with it. Just pay the $100 cleanup fee.- Parts that you are repairing break quite often. When fully leveled, you have a 90% chance to repair a part, but you do not FULLY repair it. This means that you roll those dice multiple times per part. They really should've had a decrease in condition by a random amount if that 10% chance comes up, but instead, the thing is totally borked. So if you have a part that is in poor condition so that you need to hit "repair" 4 times to get it fully to 100%, then you actually have a chance that is 90%*90%*90%*90%, or about 66% chance of getting it fully repaired and 34% chance of breaking it entirely and paying to replace it. That may not sound bad, but that is what it is like when you're at max level. - DLC. Gross. Well, it's not AWFUL, but here's the thing: the "Gold" version of this game only includes some of the DLC. Most of the rest of it adds actual brand name vehicles to the lineup. So, since they have to pay to use those brands, it makes some sense. Even so, it leaves a bitter taste in my mouth to buy the Gold version and not even get the majority of the DLC.The Ugly:- The game actually looks very nice on the whole, but the textures for new parts sometimes doesn't say "shiny chrome" so much as it does "plastic thing painted to look like shiny chrome."- Some of the paint colors are pretty awful.... well, just like with real-life cars, truthfully. Many of them are quite nice, but it seems like you're more likely to wind up with something pretty ugly. You can paint them a new color, but you really can't preview a car's color very well in the paint shop without paying to have it painted, which means that tweaking that color can get kinda expensive.

Posted: October 29, 2016
												As someone who really works on cars, I'd say this is a failry accurate mechanic sim without the grazed knuckles and frustration of hard to get to bolts.Very similar to games such as Gearhead Garage and Street Legal, this game puts you in charge of your own workshop. You make money fixing customers cars which you can then spend on buying cars at auction. The auction cars always need some work, when the work is complete you can either add the car to your garage, or sell it for a profit.I am restoring a DeLorean in real life so I also grabbed the DeLorean DLC. It's pretty accurate, although some things in the engine bay are in the wrong place and the DeLorean in this game has a power steering pump instead of an A/C unit, but I understand this is probably a limitation of the game engine. It did feel weird taking the mix unit and intake manifold off to inspect the Valley of Death as I have done on my own DeLorean.I've had hours of fun, the only downside to the game is it can get repetitive. quite a lot of the customer jobs are big jobs such as rebuilding the entire front and back suspension system, which is time consuming and monotonous. Having said that, life as a real mechanic would be very similar. There is also not much you can do with your own cars once they have been rebuilt, apart from sit in them or take them around a test track.Overall I'd recommend this game to anyone who has an interest in pulling cars and engines to bits and at the moment this is probably THE best game on the market for anyone wanting a modern Gearhead Garage clone.

Posted: August 12, 2016
Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 (CMS 15) is exactly what is sounds like: a car mechanic simulator. The player takes the role of a mechanic in your very own garage. As you build up a good reputation and learn more, you get to work on harder, more complex vehicles. You are given hints early on to help you determine exactly what parts to fix or replace, but soon those nice yellow outlines will disappear, and you're on your own. Cars get nicer, and so do your payouts.Car Mechanic Sim is literally all I hoped it to be. I wanted to learn more about how cars come together, and it did the job perfectly for me. While it's not a 100% accurate simulation, the game does a good job of giving you the gist of certain aspects of how a car works. Before playing CMS15, I wouldn't have known how suspension even works in cars. I really like working on older cars, such as muscle cars and other little classic cars, because of how different they are from modern designs, especially the engines and the suspension setups.ProsGood basic learning toolLots of inexpensive DLCs to expand the gameplay (licensed brands, tuning options)Good array of cars parodied from real-world vehicles.ConsNot a full car simulation! It's a mechanic sim!Gets progressively more difficult (could be interpreted either way really, just putting it in the cons because it has more weight as a con) The gameplay is a bit repetitive after a while. You may like to try the challenge mode to mix things up a bit!Final Thoughts:CMS is a good way to pass time and learn something while doing it!Rating: 9.0/10This review was written for and is published on the  Lit Reviews [LR] curator page.

Posted: January 4, 2016
												I enjoyed this more than I thought I would. I'm not really that into cars, but there was something strangely satisfying about figuring out what was wrong with the cars and then fixing them. Then it was fun buying junkers in auctions, stripping them down, and rebuilding them. But it all got a bit repetitive after a while. After I'd torn apart every kind of engine and suspension there wasn't much left new to discover. The game could be a lot deeper if it was harder to get parts for some of the cars. Then rebuilding them would be much more of a challenge. But after a while, money is plentiful and you can basically get any part you want, so there's not much challenge any more. Anyway, I still recommend it and enjoyed my time with the game. I got a good 25 hours out of it before feeling like I had seen everything.

Posted: January 4, 2016
												I recommend this game only to people that want to learn about cars and all of the parts. This game should be a prerequisite training for AutoZone staff, or people that want to have a general understanding of what they're talking about around mechanics and other car people. If you already know it all, you probably won't enjoy this game.2015 is MUCH better than the previous 2014 version. A lot of the navigational frustrations and problematic kinks have been worked out, making the disassembly and assembly of the parts a breeze. When you're unable to remove a part due to another part in the way, the game now highlights the obstacle part for you. In this way the game is highly focused on teaching you, rather than challenging you to show off what you already know. If you already know everything about cars, this game will seem very repetitive and dull. The game counters this by changing the types of engines and cars that arrive so that you will familiarize yourself with searching for the same parts in different car-model setups and slowly introducing additional concepts such as compression checks, electrical meters, OBD, etc.But for players that want to learn, it's a perfect example of gaming that can teach you something that you can use in life. We already see other games that do this in teaching instruments: Synthesia teaches piano, Rocksmith teaches guitar, etc. This is another example of gaming with UTILITY!!!The game goes a bit further with integrating real-life scenarios and descriptions of car problems that mechanics may face such as "my steering is loose," "my brakes are loud," and "there's not much power in the engine." Is it as close to real-life as possible? Of course not. It's very basic, but not a substitute for hands-on experience. IRL, mechanics will be cursing at the rusted bolt that won't loosen until it slips and they bloody up their knuckles. They'll spend hours trying to figure out an anomoly and burn their elbows on an exhaust manifold and proceed to throw their wrench across the garage and storm off for a smoke break. So you have to give it credit for what it does best - teaches basic car parts and understanding. This is also not a game where you try to rush through to gain XP and money. That will just set you up for getting annoyed that you have to change out yet another stupid brake disk when it's the 5th one you've changed in the past hour. It's designed to teach through repetition, at times.A few of the bad: the camera angles can be a bit tricky to view the parts, but it has been dramatically improved over CM Sim 2014. Some of the tasks can be repetitive as I mentioned earlier. The upgrades and rewards aren't phenomenal. In conclusion, a great game and learning tool. I'd like to see more of these simulators that offer utility, not just entertainment alone.

Posted: March 24
												Lots of fun, with only a couple downsides. I definitely recommend giving it a try, especially if you get some of the DLCs to go with it, and/or get it on sale.The major negative is the loading screens. Holy crap. I'm running an i7 with the game installed on an SSD, and it's still bad. Using the repair bench and working on a car is fine, but anything past that is just awful. The drag strip, test track, auction house, parking lot... all take a ridiculously long time to load. It's enough that I basically never use them anymore (except the auction house, which is a big part of the end game content).The only other real negative worth mentioning is that there is no real satisfying ending. It's just the same gameplay loop over and over- buy car at auction (or accept work order), fix it, finish. With some DLC, you can also do some tuning to the car to get better performance, but this is never requested in a work order. It's a nice addition, but not really tied into the care gameplay in any meaningful way. Other DLC adds performance parts and additional cars... which is cool, but again not really changing the core gameplay. Once you've seen all the car models and done all the upgrades, there's really nothing more to do except "do it again". The DLCs really just extend the game out a little further before you hit that. I've got most of the DLCs and 65 hours in the game... and I still enjoy it, but I'm definitely feeling like I've run out of things to do.And finally, there's very little in the way of a 3rd party / modding community. The game apparently doesn't lend itself well to that. It's never going to be anything more than what you get out of the box (plus DLCs).However, the core gameplay is pretty fun. I've never been a mechanic or even worked on cars beyond pretty simple things, but I really enjoyed it. I doubt the accuracy is all that great, but the core concepts line up reasonably well with what I do know, and it's fun to play around. You can even be a "shady" mechanic if you want by removing good parts and putting bad ones on in their place (though I found doing so to be too time-consuming, personally).I recommend the Gold or Platinum edition, especially if you can get them on sale.

Posted: September 13, 2016
												Overall I really enjoy this game. I really feel like this is a spiritual successor to a much older game that some car enthusiasts might be familiar with ("Gearhead Garage"). There are a lot of welcome improvements over the 2014 version of the game such as the ability to buy cars from the auction and sell them. The variety of cars is good and I like how there is an actual variety of how you assemble the vehicles. The graphics are pretty nice. Some of the game modes such as the test track and the paint booth seem a little underdeveloped in my opinion (as in the steering is a little difficult and the paint booth is pretty simplistic in terms of color choice.) The DLCs are pretty reasonably priced for the content in them. The only two things that bother me to any extent in the game is that you have to put a LOT of time into the game before you are able to access the auction block. I feel like the real highlight of the game is the ability to buy cars in various condition at the auction and then fix them up to sell them. Along with the auction sequence comes my second issue with the game: you should be able to put the car up for auction as opposed to outright selling it, and the work order screen should have some information on how much of a total monetary and time investment you have in the car.  With those things said, I don't think that they interfere with my enjoyment of the game to the extent that I would quit playing it or that I wouldn't recommend it.I bought the game as a bundle with a lot of its DLC included. I would buy it again. I would recommend it to others that are interested in cars and simulation games.

Posted: May 11, 2016
Highly recommended for fans of motors, cars, or puzzle games.Yeah. That's what I'd call this at the end of the day--a puzzle game.Generally it goes like this: Someone comes in with a car and tells you what's wrong with it--or rather as much as they can. In the beginning this is usually a description like "Loud exhaust" or "Strange knocking sounds", and then a full list of parts. You then go buy those parts for the customer, go in, and find and replace them. Eventually however the game stops holding your hand. You're given the description of the problem, and a list of the NUMBER of parts that need replacing, but you're not told which ones they are. You have to go in and manually inspect the engine, or the exhaust, or the transmission, and you have to diagnose those problems yourself. It's challenging, it's fun, and it's all the great parts about working on a car with none of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.It's a really cool game, and the DLC just makes it even cooler, with the addition of aftermarket parts, engine swaps, and new cars to play with. The DLC are VERY appropriately priced as well, each one adding just enough content to justify their price without feeling like a ripoff or a total steal.The only thing I can possibly complain about is the god forsaken soundtrack. It's ♥♥♥♥ing awesome, but there are literally like... 4 or 5 songs that just play over and over--I suppose it's a rather realistic simulation of listening to the radio, but without any ads or DJs. Thankfully though, you can mute that♥♥♥♥♥♥ So when you get tired of the music--and you will--just go put on some hair metal and get back to thrashing.

Posted: December 27, 2015
												A must have for a car nut! I love the game. I have worked on cars before and mostly everything is spot on - especially suspension wise. There are some parts that have either been omitted or overly simplified but - especially engine wise - but it's no big deal. It performs well but has a few weird quirks. I could not get the game to load until a user suggested I force-minimize the game via CTRL+ALT+DEL, then go back in, which oddly enough worked out.PROS:- Fun and educational- Very accurate parts wise- Great visuals- Nice testing tools- Good experience points and unlocks- Nice soundtrack (in my opinion)CONS:- Odd performance quirks at times- Long and frequent loading times- Some overly simplified engine components- Camera fights with you sometimesSUGGESTIONS FOR CMS 2016:- Let's get deeper into engine parts! I realize it might turn away some folks because engines can get very complex. Perhaps a difficulty setting where this is adjustable?- Automatic transmissions. Every car in this game is a manual. Autos would be nice as they would introduce a whole new category of drivetrains.- The aftermarket scene. I realize this is probably a can of worms, but a few performance mods wouldn't hurt. It's not uncommon for people to take their cars to shops and request performance parts. Throw in a dyno too!

Don't get me wrong for me it is still fun but would be better if there was more difference between the vehicles.Brake jobs - Too easySuspension - Too easyEngine Work - Needs more varietyTransmission - Too easyDrivetrain - Too easyIgnition System - Too easyFuel system - Too easyBody Work - Too easyAll in all i would say it is too easy of a game for someone like me who has experience and a vast knowledge of how vehicles function & are built.Just a word of advice... Do not think you can be a mechanic after playing this game. You will be pleasently disappointed.

Posted: September 13, 2016
												Overall I really enjoy this game. I really feel like this is a spiritual successor to a much older game that some car enthusiasts might be familiar with ("Gearhead Garage"). There are a lot of welcome improvements over the 2014 version of the game such as the ability to buy cars from the auction and sell them. The variety of cars is good and I like how there is an actual variety of how you assemble the vehicles. The graphics are pretty nice. Some of the game modes such as the test track and the paint booth seem a little underdeveloped in my opinion (as in the steering is a little difficult and the paint booth is pretty simplistic in terms of color choice.) The DLCs are pretty reasonably priced for the content in them. The only two things that bother me to any extent in the game is that you have to put a LOT of time into the game before you are able to access the auction block. I feel like the real highlight of the game is the ability to buy cars in various condition at the auction and then fix them up to sell them. Along with the auction sequence comes my second issue with the game: you should be able to put the car up for auction as opposed to outright selling it, and the work order screen should have some information on how much of a total monetary and time investment you have in the car.  With those things said, I don't think that they interfere with my enjoyment of the game to the extent that I would quit playing it or that I wouldn't recommend it.I bought the game as a bundle with a lot of its DLC included. I would buy it again. I would recommend it to others that are interested in cars and simulation games.
