Posted: April 29, 2016
												Cons: *Not many cars*Most of the songs are what can only be described as "electronic fart noises that 6 year old kids listen to while they play Minecraft." A few songs are tolerable, but you'll probably want to play this game on mute to avoid the tasteless music and incessant phone-ringing. *The auction system is a complete joke. If you don't show interest in a car, the AI won't bid on it at all. If you so much as bid on a car once, the AI will spam it with bids until a car with a starting bid of $4,000 has well over $40,000 in bids. All exaggeration aside, the last car I bought  started at around $20,000 and ended at over $60,000. At $500 per bid and a $40,0000 raise, that's 80 bids. 80. "Come ONNNNNNN, JUST LET ME BUY THE CAR." is something you'll probably say to yourself a lot. *It's pretty repetitive. Unbolt this part, beat on it with a hammer until it breaks, buy a new one. You'll be running back and forth to your PC a lot, so I suggest that your first upgrade point goes to a tablet. It'll save you a lot of time and frustation.*Did I mention that there aren't many cars? I think there are maybe 10 different ones. I also got the Fiat DLC for free, somehow, but I don't think everyone else will. Still, not nearly enough cars for this price point. The lack of variety really makes it even more repetitive than it already is. *Not much driving going on. After you finish restoring your poorly-modeled, generic-looking knock off of a Peugeot 505, you might want to drive it. Your options are a small skidpad that was ripped off from Beam MG Drive, or the testing area. *Poor car models. Looks more like CMS 2012, but I still can't run it at the highest settings on my PC with 6 GIGs of memory. Medium-high settings at around 30 FPS. *The customer orders are tedius and more or less all the same. "Loud exhaust, fix all driveline issues, repair all body panels." Every time. Every single time. It's always the same problems with every car. *You need 9,000 XP and $50,000 to unlock the garage and be able to auction and restore cars, which is probably the only thing in the game worth doing. It took me about 16 hours to get to that point, give or take. So it'll take roughly 16 hours to get to the point in the game where it'll be worth playing, but then you need to do more customer jobs to raise money to buy and repair cars, because buying the parking lot and other parts of the garage will eat up most of your money at the beginning of the game. *Overpriced, along with the DLC. It would be a great game for $10, and $15 including the DLC. *There's not really any simulation going on. Everything is too simplified and easy. Maybe I'm just not in the age group for the target demographic or something. There's a lot more to a car than 50 bolts and some body panels. *So [loading]  many [loading] loading screens. Why. How could this game possibly need this many loading screens? Need to scratch your nose? Loading screen. Go to the auction? 2 loading screens, and then 2 or 3 going back to your garage. And just for the fun of it, a loading screen to launch a loading screen. It's like being on Oprah when she decides that everyone wins a loading screen. "YOU get a loading screen! YOU get a loading screen! EVERYBODY GETS A LOADING SCREEN!" Pros:*I guess it's pretty entertaining for a little while. While what little charm it had wore thin a long time ago, I still enjoy it. I honestly don't think my enjoyment of the game makes up for everything else. It's not good, and not bad. It's basically the definition of mediocre. Edit: If you look at it as a car-based puzzle game, you'll be a little better off. As a car mechanic simulator, it's not that good. As a car-based puzzle game, you'll have a hard time finding something better. I don't have much of the DLC, but I'm sure with the cool cars they've added on it'll be even better. Not everyone will like this game, maybe even most people. I still like it. It's relaxing, though a bit tedius sometimes. You don't need to know much about cars at all to play it. Just pay attention to what parts need to be removed in what order and you'll be okay. Would I recommend this game? Probably not. It seems to have a pretty specific audience. That doesn't make it a bad game, but not everyone will find it enjoyable. And I feel like a small Eastern European game company who tries their best to make a good game deserves a good amount of support.Like others said, it seems pretty pointless that you can't customize your cars in the base game. Also, you get the parts from the DLC cars in your parts catalogue for the DLC cars, even if you don't have the DLC.

Posted: March 24
												Lots of fun, with only a couple downsides. I definitely recommend giving it a try, especially if you get some of the DLCs to go with it, and/or get it on sale.The major negative is the loading screens. Holy crap. I'm running an i7 with the game installed on an SSD, and it's still bad. Using the repair bench and working on a car is fine, but anything past that is just awful. The drag strip, test track, auction house, parking lot... all take a ridiculously long time to load. It's enough that I basically never use them anymore (except the auction house, which is a big part of the end game content).The only other real negative worth mentioning is that there is no real satisfying ending. It's just the same gameplay loop over and over- buy car at auction (or accept work order), fix it, finish. With some DLC, you can also do some tuning to the car to get better performance, but this is never requested in a work order. It's a nice addition, but not really tied into the care gameplay in any meaningful way. Other DLC adds performance parts and additional cars... which is cool, but again not really changing the core gameplay. Once you've seen all the car models and done all the upgrades, there's really nothing more to do except "do it again". The DLCs really just extend the game out a little further before you hit that. I've got most of the DLCs and 65 hours in the game... and I still enjoy it, but I'm definitely feeling like I've run out of things to do.And finally, there's very little in the way of a 3rd party / modding community. The game apparently doesn't lend itself well to that. It's never going to be anything more than what you get out of the box (plus DLCs).However, the core gameplay is pretty fun. I've never been a mechanic or even worked on cars beyond pretty simple things, but I really enjoyed it. I doubt the accuracy is all that great, but the core concepts line up reasonably well with what I do know, and it's fun to play around. You can even be a "shady" mechanic if you want by removing good parts and putting bad ones on in their place (though I found doing so to be too time-consuming, personally).I recommend the Gold or Platinum edition, especially if you can get them on sale.

Posted: March 11, 2016
												In many ways, this game is the best car mechanic simulator we've ever seen, which earn it a thumbs up.  Some improvements really need to be made and most of all, I'm terribly unimpressed with the new game release for the year rather than properly updating the game (Car Mechanic Simulator 2014) that we've already paid for - bad form.Positive:- Various systems in the car to work on- Easy to remove/add parts and repair them (once you unlock that option)- Buy used cars through an action and refurbish them- Decent soundtrack- Easy to move around in the shopNegative:- It can be difficult to get to the part you want to change/affect; it's hard to move around on the actual cars once you're trying to affect them- When in the mode to re-add parts, the opaque white overlay is difficult to see at times.- No explanation for some features such as the extra rooms, how to get to auction, old game test track (how would you even know this exists?) - I personally took "Exit" for leave the game, not "Go to other areas"- Various game crashes, mostly involving the Unity engine; telling me to play in Windows 7 mode really isn't an answer.Overall, I love it for being the current best at what it does but at the same time I hate it for what might have been.

												Fantastic game.I really enjoyed playing this one, my friend had this on his account and I had a go and ended up playing it for 10 hours over a couple of days and had to purchase it. I like cars irl and know a small ammount about mechanics and the simulator is a great way of learning some of the basic parts of a car and get a rough idea of where everything goes. However, it isn't realistic in that you would be able to take the knowledge to the real thing, although any hobbyist mechanic may find some use for this.Away from the eduactional side of things and on to the gameplay. The game is really fun at first but it does start to grind on whilst you raise your level and gain enough money to hit the auctions. However, once you have done this grind it will be well worth it because the game so much more interesting and fun when you can buy old bangers and suke them up into high powered machines to either race around or sell for a high profit.One of my favorite games.Pro'sReally well designed and easy to learnHelps learning names and places of actual car partsGood end game contentHighly replayableNice graphicsAwesome soundtrackCon'sSome of the DLC seems rather overpriced for what it addsProbably extremely boring if you have no interest in cars or mechanicsI highly recomend this game to anyone with an interest in cars/mechanics but I would say that if you don't have much interest try a demo or something first as my friend who owns this finds it really dull.

												I'm no expert when it comes to cars but this game has got my attention, I bought this game not only to have fun but to learn car parts as well. The game is really fun (seriously), especially if you buy the Performance DLC because you can modify your own car even more like swapping engines! Unfortunately there's no tutorial, at least for the control. You won't be guided what to do to fix the car, you'll be given list of parts that needs to be replaced and that's it (I even search Google Image to find the location of the part xD). If you gain enough XP there will be more challenges, like you need to find the broken parts yourself. Soon you'll get tools like OBD Scanner to help you examine broken parts faster and more easily.---------------------------The game's pretty small though, unlike game like Euro Truck Simulator 2 where you can name you company, hire staff, travel between countries. This game only let you work inside a garage alone, so this game can be boring after you play the game for a while. Well you can test cars in a test track, buy your own personal car, and have a drag race but that's basically it. Even so, to purchase your own car, you need to get a parking lot, which require lots of XP to be able to purchase it.---------------------------You should purchase this game if you're interested in cars, because believe me, you'll be fixing cars all day long and if you're not into it you'll ditch the game right away.

Posted: July 31, 2015
												"An Investment in Automotive Education" While this game is not even close to a 100% representation of actual car functions or mechanic duties, I can honestly say that i know so much more about cars than i did before i started playing this. The first large chunk of this game will be occupied by repair jobs, where you will be required to find broken parts in the car and fix them. When enough experience and money is gathered, the real fun begins when you can purchase your own cars, then restore them and either sell them, or keep them for your own personal collection. The DLC for this game is fairly priced, but is not necessary to enjoy the game. Anyone who has an interest in cars, or just wants to learn more about cars should certainly pick up this game. It is fully worth the $19.99 price, but if its on sale, there is hardly an excuse to not give this a try.

Posted: October 29, 2016
												As someone who really works on cars, I'd say this is a failry accurate mechanic sim without the grazed knuckles and frustration of hard to get to bolts.Very similar to games such as Gearhead Garage and Street Legal, this game puts you in charge of your own workshop. You make money fixing customers cars which you can then spend on buying cars at auction. The auction cars always need some work, when the work is complete you can either add the car to your garage, or sell it for a profit.I am restoring a DeLorean in real life so I also grabbed the DeLorean DLC. It's pretty accurate, although some things in the engine bay are in the wrong place and the DeLorean in this game has a power steering pump instead of an A/C unit, but I understand this is probably a limitation of the game engine. It did feel weird taking the mix unit and intake manifold off to inspect the Valley of Death as I have done on my own DeLorean.I've had hours of fun, the only downside to the game is it can get repetitive. quite a lot of the customer jobs are big jobs such as rebuilding the entire front and back suspension system, which is time consuming and monotonous. Having said that, life as a real mechanic would be very similar. There is also not much you can do with your own cars once they have been rebuilt, apart from sit in them or take them around a test track.Overall I'd recommend this game to anyone who has an interest in pulling cars and engines to bits and at the moment this is probably THE best game on the market for anyone wanting a modern Gearhead Garage clone.

Posted: June 12, 2016
												Other people have said this before but this isn't really a sim. This is more of a puzzle game involving various car and engine parts. The great thing about it is that there are several types of engines to fix, each with there own unique parts. Fixing them is a lot of fun but the thing i like the most about it is buying cars at an auction and completely restore it and then sell it for big profits. It takes a while to get enough experience and buy the upgrades necessary to do so but its a lot of fun. One car consist out of so many parts and it can be a little tricky when you disassemble them and replace all the defective parts. The only downside to this game are the long loading times (considering the game has to load a lot of parts) and even on a PC that exceeds way above the minimum specs may take a several moments. All in all, this doesn't form much of a problem to me. Another thing i don't like is the music in this game. It's all dubstep and its like listening to a 56k modem making musical tones. Luckily, it can be turned off so that you can play your own music.     All in all, its a great game and the DLC adds new features and cars. Currently, there's a Mercedes-Benz DLC that adds the 300 SL Gullwing and the 560 SEC. There are more real life cars to come, now that the developers acquired the license for Maserati. Can't wait!

Posted: July 4, 2016
												I'm no expert when it comes to cars but this game has got my attention, I bought this game not only to have fun but to learn car parts as well. The game is really fun (seriously), especially if you buy the Performance DLC because you can modify your own car even more like swapping engines! Unfortunately there's no tutorial, at least for the control. You won't be guided what to do to fix the car, you'll be given list of parts that needs to be replaced and that's it (I even search Google Image to find the location of the part xD). If you gain enough XP there will be more challenges, like you need to find the broken parts yourself. Soon you'll get tools like OBD Scanner to help you examine broken parts faster and more easily.---------------------------The game's pretty small though, unlike game like Euro Truck Simulator 2 where you can name you company, hire staff, travel between countries. This game only let you work inside a garage alone, so this game can be boring after you play the game for a while. Well you can test cars in a test track, buy your own personal car, and have a drag race but that's basically it. Even so, to purchase your own car, you need to get a parking lot, which require lots of XP to be able to purchase it.---------------------------You should purchase this game if you're interested in cars, because believe me, you'll be fixing cars all day long and if you're not into it you'll ditch the game right away.

Posted: July 29, 2016
												This is a pretty entertaining game, even for a light/heavy line auto technician who does the real life stuff. Its great to pass the time with, learn a little (for the average individual who doesn't do this kind of work), and enjoy a game for those who have the automotive passion. Most average players won't notice the mistakes, but it's understandbly not 100% realistic. A couple examples are: The "power steering pump" looks exactly like an A/C compressor on most models. Also, I had no idea a belt driven radiator fan could bolt up to nothing with four bolts in FRONT of the radiator. And lastly, coming from someone who does this kind work in reality......don't spend an hour with frustration on how to drop the fuel tank or try to remove the back seat in a car to change the fuel pump in the top of the tank. You know, the usual, real life step you would have to take. Because none of that works or is apparently needed. You can apparently just remove the fuel pump in the tank that's buried in the car. Makes no sense. Real world thinking screwed me there for a bit.Anyway, game doesn't have any bugs. No glitches or issues with playability.All in all, not too bad of a game. I enjoy it.

												 Car Mechanic 2015 is a definite improvement from the 2014 version. There is a lot more detail in the work you do to the cars. I find myself not wanting to stop playing. I finish one job and I tell myself this is the last one I'm going to do today, then I start looking at the next job and find myself working on it till I finish. It is very addictive!  If you know nothing about cars, Car Mechanic 2015 will help you understand the basics of what is what on a car an where it can be found!I can't get enough of this game! I have had no issues with the game play at all! If you don't have it yet, get it, you'll love it!  Since I am a trained mechanic myself there are a few things that should be added to the next version, if there is going to be next version, like powers tools! Instead of using the ratchet sounds add in some power tool sound fx! Like the impact wrench and an air wratchet! These would make the game even more enjoyable! Also custom paint jobs woud be really cool as well! Something where you could have a set of custom designs the customer would like to put on their car and paint it in the paint booth! Even metallic colors would look great! Something for the designers to think about! I have a lot of ideas for future Car Mechanic Simulators! This game is well worth the money! Two thumbs up from me! Definitly on the top of my gaming list!

Posted: June 20, 2015
												There are quite a lot of pros and only a few cons to the game. Mind you, I will be comparing the older version to the newer version.Pros:-It is not very laggy: The biggest issue I had with the older version was that I set my game to the lowest video settings, but I still kept on lagging. This game takes that and throws it in the bin. With the same computer and same specs, the 2015 version was much more smoother than the 2014 version. I had at least 30fps all the way, whereas I would have 15-20fps on the 2014 version. -Interesting Campaign Mode: The one in CMS2014 was very controlled, you were given the same puzzle as everyone else who played the game. This gives you the choice to select the orders you want to take, and that is a game changer. No longer do you HAVE to do an order. You get to pick what you want to do. i.e I don't feel like fixing that guy's brakes, so I'll just select the order with the engine problems instead. This helps to make the game much more smoother and much more playable.-Much fewer glitches: I had a problem with CMS2014, and that was my order #43 glitched and I couldn't finish the order no matter how closely I followed the instructions. Since this is a newer game, we don't have as many glitches anymore. This game is being constantly updated, so it allows for improvement all the time. -Cool DLCs: We have had two DLCs come out by the time I am writing this review, Visual Tuning and Young Timer. Young Timer is free, with the nice little Fiat 500 lookalike. The Visual Tuning DLC does cost some money, however it is much more cheaper compared to the price tags on the other DLCs. Cons:-Time Consuming: Unless you are an absolute car bore who likes fixing the cars in this game like I do, you are not going to have a fun time. This is a simulator of what mechanics do on a daily basis, so ofcourse it is going to be time consuming, what did you expect? -Unlockables: In CMS2014, we had the OBD scanner as a tool since the beginning of the game. Why do we need to work on 10 cars maximum in order to unlock the tool that we had for a long time in the previous game? They could've let some tools remain like they were in the previous game. However, it does add for an interesting aspect to the gameplay, because now you get to work for the things you really want. Although that is interesting to me, it might not be to the other gamers. -Repair Uncertainty: Now again, unless you are a car enthusiast that finds these innovations interesting to the gameplay, you are probably not going to like the fact that there is a chance that the item you repair may not be fixed successfully. Overall, I think they did an excellent job with the new 2015 simulator. The new additional features are absolutely worth every single penny of that price tag. This new game completely demolishes the other older one, and I am not saying this because my CMS2014 Order #43 did not work. I genuinely believe this new game is a huge step forward from the previous one. I can now only imagine how much greater the 2016 version will be, definitely a rival to the upcoming Street Tuning Revolution. I am only joking, that game is a total in depth tuning game and it will take Red Dot Games a little while to catch up to that level, eventhough in my opinion it is very close. Then again, I have not played Street Tuning Evolution yet, so I can't tell the gap there might exist between the two games. CMS2016, that is a game definitely to look forward to.

												There are only so many ways you change a tire (or what have you)...so extremely repetive.That being said, addictive as heck if you are in to click-and-point stuff and car engineering in general. Fairly steady supply of patches and dlcs so far, so while being the same "fix broken stuff" keeps things semi-fresh. Only once you've maxxed out your shop and filled up your garage you really run out of stuff to do (at that point money isn't an issue either).The expert mode is a good addition once you're familiar with the game as it adds an extra layer to the fixes (only gives a generic fault description ie. Posted: April 15, 2016
												This game is literally working in a car repair shop withhout oil and mess all over your hands, without missing nuts and bolts and of course, being in the comfort of your home. The game becomes more fun when you can buy your own cars and fix them up, however eventually you would have fixed so many cars, that it would be a bit boring after some time. The dev's have been releasing DLC's frequently though, so that we have more cars to mingle around with. Recently the Mercedes DLC came out, now THAT was a suprise. here are the Pro's and Con's about this game.Pro's-Wide variety of cars-Huge amount of customization for the garages-Bodykits and new rims if you get the DLC-Nice and simple auction system-Upgrades that make it more convenient in-game, for eg. faster un-bolting times, portable tablet for easy purchase of parts etcCon's-Bad inventory organising and sorting-Small and confined area to test your cars-Interior of cars are never damaged, torn or worn-Strange driving physics Overall I feel this is a great game for car enthusiasts and is not over complicated for those who are still extending their knowlage of cars, this game runs very smoothly on my MacBook Air and should do well on a PC running core i5 and has 4GB of ram.

The problem was the fuel pump in the fuel tank at the back of the car.Smacked myself in the head, replaced the fuel pump and had to put the whole engine back together.10/10 would do it again.

Posted: January 24
												Car Mechanic 2015 is interesting. I foresee this game striking only certain gamers, but if you question whether you will like this game or not, you should buy it because you're curious. The game itself won't let you down. Graphically the game is top notch compared to CM2014. The intriguing part about the game is about what it offers. The DLC is fun, you can completely tear down a vehicle inside and out, work orders, buy a garage to stow extra vehicles, go to auctions, there's test tracks, a DYNO, and paint vehicles. I'm sure I left out other cool stuff. The best way to play this game is to sit back, put on some music, and work on fixing several different cars.

Posted: November 2, 2015
												Around 6 hours into the game I've done about 8 cars.The game tends to hold your hand a lot, and everything is pretty straight forward. So far it has been more of a point and click simulator than a car mechanic simulator but it is still fairly entertaining.Not knowing anything about what goes on under the hood myself, the game has been somewhat educational in showing me where and what parts are that I've only seen on a repair/service bill. I do think with a little more time put into the game I might actually be able to go out to my car and identify them myself.For a simulator title, the game is very simplistic. Taking off parts is as simple as holding down a mouse button, and when you need to unbolt or unscrew something the same applies. When putting something back onto the car, you are provided with silhouettes of missing parts. This makes assembly fairly simple almost to the point of being too easy.Most of the cars have been more of the same, and I can see the game getting very repetitive quickly. The only difference in difficulty boils down to how extensively you will need to strip the car to get to the broken part. This becomes more of a chore than a difficulty factor. Speaking of broken parts, the only indication of this is rust. Parts do not have cracks etc. The only indication of wear on parts is rust. This makes most of the problems you fix linear and adds to repetition.All of this taken into account, you would think I would not recommend the game. However the game is fun in a zen repetition kind of way, and there is some novelty to the learning experience. My first maluch (old) car was more interesting since I had even less of an idea of where everything is, and I even left out some parts when putting the engine back together xDIf this is something that interests you, and the price is right, give it a try. But don't expect too much realism or much of a challenge.

Posted: March 17
												Short Version: Disassembly and reassembly is great but that is really all there is to it. Other functions are more of an add on with bare minimum to call it a function. Think original SIMS Pets mod.Decent game. Not too much to it but still fun enough that I feel like I got my 20 bucks worth and I did buy some of the DLC packs. Most of it revolves around taking apart cars and reassembly. There is really not much to it. You do not get penalized or rewarded for taking your time with it. You can end the job at any point and still get paid for work you did. Even during a ride, you cannot damage the cars (or dragging). The only thing that is negative is if you don’t put oil collecting thing under the car and get fined 100 bucks for the cleanup. Once you do enough jobs you get the option to buy Junkers and repair them than sell them or drag them. But that pretty much it. You only get one static shop. Jobs will come in no matter what you do. There is no bigger space to move in. There is no managing a garage, hiring other mechanics. No cliental or cliental review to give you more or less work. This is a very simple (detail oriented down to the screws) take a car apart and put it together.

Posted: January 11
												This a really cool game, but it's not something for everyone. I'll start out by saying that it's actually pretty fun repairing cars in this game, but if repairing cars is a game concept you dislike or don't think would be fun in any way, maybe this game isn't for you. I'm not a person who likes cars, but the idea seemed intriguing, and sure enough, I really liked the game. Now I'm going to give you some personal likes and dislikes about the game. I can't say it enough that these are my likes and dislikes and they are not factualLikes:- The game generally is quite educational. You generally learn about car parts and maybe what they do.- The game has a good learning curve. It generally doesn't throw a lot of tutorials at you, though I do think that it has one at the start- You can buy different old and broken car at an auction so that you can repair it. You can either choose to keep or sell it. That generally adds something new after you've learned practically everything.Dislikes:*- The games feels quite repetitive after about 30-40 hours or so. - I would have liked there to have been a bigger selection of cars. There's is actually a lot of different cars, but what I mean is that more variety, since a lot of the cars look the same on the inside.*The dislikes mentioned could probably have been solved by me bying the gold edition instead of the regular edition, but I don't have it so screw me right?All in all I would probably give it a 7/10**Do keep in mind, that if this doesn't sound intriguing to you, you definatly shouldn't buy this game. If it does sound intriguing to you, you should probably go for the gold or platinum edition instead, since they give A LOT more content that the regular version**

Posted: December 18, 2016
												In it you have your own shop. You pick up the phone and accept or not the jobs. Some of them have a list of the parts you have to change, some of them not (which i prefer).Once the car is in your shop, you can visualy inspect parts for condition. After you earn some XP, you can buy skills (equipments) that you make the "ispection job" a lot easier. You then disassemble, change parts and assemble the car back together.I must say, not everybody will like its gameplay style, but as an Aircraft Mechanic myself, I feel like this game was made for me.I really hope they will make newer versions (maybe 2017?)P.S.: I really wish we could open the gearboxes though.

Posted: December 17, 2016
												I now have ~13hours of play time, enough for a review I think.Overall: Solid, fun game, but short.I started in normal mode and I was really happy with this game. The setup of the shop, moving cars around. Inspecting, removing, (repairing) and finishing the job is all great fun. After a couple of hours though I feel like parts of the car are missing. The engine and suspension are done pretty well in this game. Other than that I thought few parts of the car are in the game extensively.So I switched to epert mode and this gives a new challenge. Almost all info and hints are gone, which makes it hader and more fun. After a while though you kinda feel like you know all the parts in the game and even in expert mode you dismantle and reassemble the cars with ease. The disciption on expert mode says you need to know where al the screws are, but really if you just "screw around" in the general area of the part, that does job too.In conclusion. It's fun to investigate where the bad parts of the car are, repair and put the car back together. Engine and suspension parts are well done in this game (I guess). That is why I recommend this game on sale. After a while (~10-12hours), you know the parts by heart and its old. For his to be really great I'ld like maybe a fusebox or the inner parts of the gearbox or even just windshield wipers and fluid levels. This game is good enough for me, but it could be awesome.

Posted: December 30, 2016
												Much more fun that you'd initially expect; I thought I'd drop a few minutes in, 4 hours later I'm wondering why the clock says 3am.  Definitely worth it at the $5 Steam sale priceThe game is great for those who don't even know where to find a spark plug or an oil filter, you'll learn a LOT about the anatomy of a car, where to find a lot of parts that you were too embarrassed to ask about before, and you'll have fun doing it!  I never knew what a camshaft was or where you'd find an intake manifold, but after seeing them in-game with the rest of the engine, I finally figured out what they do.  Swar bars? Ignition coils? Crankshafts? Learned that too!Don't expect to become a mechanic from this game - it skips a lot of the little things like bolts (eg - the gear box just comes right off while the engine is sitting in the car, it's not this simple in real life!), but like I said, you WILL learn where a lot of things are, what they're called, and won't look like a complete fool when you pop open a hood on a real car
